reviewText:
DO NOT GIVE MONEY TO THIS GAME THROUGH STEAM.  IF YOU DECIDE TO GIVE MONEY TO THIS COMPANY (and I wouldnt advise it.) ONLY USE PREPAID CARDS.

The reason for this is if you pay anyway other than prepaid you will get NX credit instead of NX prepaid. Why does it matter? Because you cant buy anything with NX credit (well nothing you would ever want to buy at least).  No you will not get a refund and no there is no way to transfer the NX you bought into a useable form.

Please either upvote this review or put an advisory about this in your own review so that people are aware of this when decideing if and how they want to spend money on this game.

Thanks

reviewText: [Note: this review was so long, it had to be continued in comments - see first reply by me for part 2. Also note that this is not your traditional dot point pro/con 5 second review. This is an editorial piece telling the story of how I fell in love with this amazing game.]\n\nAlthough I like to consider myself a true gamer-girl through and through, I have to admit that there was one single genre I'd never tried - an MMO. The whole pay to play" thing was a huge hurdle for me when I was a child
date: and so despite my fascination with the idea of such a large
hoursPlayed: everquest and the like were always out of reach.\n\nFast-forward a decade and times have unsurprisingly changed. With nearly all ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes becoming free to play
voteText: I finally had a chance to try out this genre that had piqued my interest for oh so many years. So around December 2012
helpfulPercent: I bit the bullet and started trawling through free-to-play MMO's
votesHelpful: to see what all the fuss was about. And I have to admit
votesTotal: my first choices did not live up to my expectations. I tried games like Mabinogi and Rose online
votesFunny: but the combat just felt totally clunky and painful. There was little in the way of moving and dodging
commentsCount: with most of the focus simply being on casting skills with incredibly long cast times
column16: and even longer cooldowns. Or alternatively
column17: just whacking something with a stick over and over ad nauseum
column18: before it keeled over and died. The graphics were bland
column20: and the story seemed non-existant.  I was beginning to think that I'd been seriously mislead about the nature of MMO's
column21: and that they were all essentially just fancy IRC rooms.\n\nBut then I installed a lil game called Dragon Nest. Like my previous choices
column22: I spent a large amount of time tinkering around in the character creator
column23: eventually choosing a class called - wait for it - tinkerer. This is a cute little girl of about 13
column25: when given the twin pigtail hairstyle
column26: beared more than a striking resemblence to me at that age. The similarities were quite uncanny
column27: which immediately grabbed my attention. Instead of roleplaying
column28: I was simply getting to relive my youthful days as a young teen - something which meant a lot to me
column29: being in my late 20's and utterly depressed at the fact that I'm not far off my thirties.\n\nBut the other games had nice character creations too
column30: only to be let down by the game itself. So I wasn't all that optimistic about this game either.\n\nMy pessimism was shattered the instant I entered the game world. After a short introduction scene
column31: I found myself in a beautiful snowy town
column32: decorated with x-mas items and a nice big christmas tree at the centre of town
column33: along with some really cheery christmas-y music. Not only this
column34: but I saw many other characters running around - lil tinkerers like myself
column36: and some rather charming looking clerics. The whole place was very pleasant and inviting
column37: and I really felt a warm welcome to the game and the community as a whole.\n\nAs I ambled around the town
column38: obtaining main story quests as well as side quests
column39: I noticed that the story behind this game was very well executed
column40: with lots of voice acting on all the main NPC's - a welcome change from static walls of text from mute characters that I'd encountered in nearly all my previous ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes up to this point. I was also approached by a polite warrior gentlemen
column43: kindly started explaining many of the concepts of the game to me. He also invited me into his guild
column44: which I was somewhat hesitant about as I didn't feel I would be of any use as a newbie. He assured me it was fine
column45: and that anyone was welcome. I'm glad I accepted the offer because I went on to meet many wonderful people
column46: who taught me a great deal about the game and were more than willing to help me complete tasks on many occasions.\n\nInitially however
column47: I chose to complete the dungeons solo
column48: just to get a feel for the combat in this game. This isn't really an open world MMO
column49: you simply have a town with many quests available
column50: and then you have a closed instance field outside of the town for you (and any party members)
column51: with several dungeons being accessible from that field. This makes the game suitable for a wide audience
column52: without needing too powerful of a computer (although don't get me wrong
column53: the graphics are very pleasant too!).\n\nUpon entering my first dungeon was my next pleasant surprise. The combat in this game is amazing! It was how I'd imagined all MMO's would play
column54: prior to actually playing them. I've been told this style is called an action MMO
column55: and it plays somewhat like a first person shooter / third person shooter
column56: with a huge emphasis on reaction times
column59: as well as carefully choosing the most ideal order in which to carry out attacks. It's very frantic
column60: but also very rewarding. It's easy to pick up
column61: but very hard to master. Having tried other apparent action MMO's
column62: I have to say that Dragon Nest hands down has the best combat I've ever experienced - it's THAT satisfying.\n\nI continued playing through about the first ten levels
column63: but I was alone and in truth the game didn't feel that much different to single player RPG's that I'd played. This all changed when
column64: upon my next visit to town
column65: I was invited to my first party. I think this was the point where the game stole my heart
column66: and I knew that I was going to be playing this for a long time. In fact
column67: I ended up playing for 24 hours straight that very day
column68: it was *that* endearing to me.\n\nThe game promotes teamwork heavily
column69: with many abilities to help each other out in the form of buffs
column71: heals and the like. Not only this
column72: but it was just simply fun to feel a part of something so grand. Even just chatting in town (which we ended up doing for hours) was immensely satisfying
column73: and I met over 30 friends in that first day alone.\n\nFrom this point on
column74: the game consumed me - I played it all day
column76: whenever I had the free time to do so.  I was really eager to see what would happen next in the main story
column77: while at the same time being happy to party with those of similar level (or even help those at lower level catch up to me). Before I knew it
column78: my friends list was maxed out at 100. I had to tell people to add me and just send me a message whenever they wanted to party
column79: as I had no room left on my list. Such friendships made me feel really happy - something that had been sorely lacking in my real life ever since an incident that left me scarred with PTSD
column80: during which some brutish man tried to kill me (literally) over a road rage incident. He very nearly succeeded too
column81: as he pushed my car towards a tree at 100 miles an hour
column82: which I missed by mere inches. But I digress
column83: this review is about the game not my own injustices.  I merely wished to portray that my friends here really helped me come a long way to recovering from this incident.\n\nSo back to the game now - at this point I was steadily getting through quests and making my way towards the level cap. So now is probably a good time to talk about the "pay" features that you have in any free to play MMO. Dragon Nest adheres to the policy of paid items being primarily cosmetic in function - this is not a "pay 2 win" game
column84: and there are many well known players who have not paid anything for the game at all
column85: whom are still some of the most powerful and well-geared characters on the server. Of the few items that *do* help make a character more powerful (namely jellies for enhancing items
column86: and stamps for allowing to sell certain high grade items on the market) both of these may be purchased from other players with in-game gold
column87: negating the need to spend real world cash.\n\n[Part 2 of review continued in comments to this due to length restrictions. Please don't leave your own comments guys

reviewText:
Note: This review is a bit outdated (It was made at around 70 cap). Some of my complaints might have been addressed at this point but I have not played the game recently so I cannot tell for myself. Fundamentally this review is still accurate though.
My steam time for this game is not accurate. I likely have at the very minimum 1,500~ hours in game.

tl;dr: Gameplay is solid and suprisingly good with a reasonable amount of depth. However, the grind from lowest level to max level (even with someone grinding you) can be nigh unbearable. The games optimization is hit-or-miss with many players computers as the optimization seems to be based on CPU power with it hardly if at all utilizing the GPU. In terms of class-to-class balance, the actual devs are fairly incompetent at making sure one class doesn't completely dominate the others.

In depth

Gameplay:
The gameplay of Dragon-nest is primarily fast-paced combat with heavy reliance on reflexes, ability to predict the enemy movements, and knowing your own skills. The combat has no casting bars rather relying on animations which makes you feel as though you are 'in control'. Many of the higher level skills do a satisfying amount of damage in PvE and a reasonable amount in PvP. In my experience, the end-game content (Dragon nests) often devolve DPS races to blow up the boss before it has a chance to do any of it's harder mechanics. Simply getting hit by some of these bosses could result in an instant death for you. Note: In the end-game content, after you die, you are dead until the raid (called 'nest' ingame) is complete or your entire party dies.

PVP:
PVP deserves it's own section because for many players it is simply all that matters in the game. PVP is largely player-skill based as a highly skilled player can easily combo the other player to death, giving the other player no opportunities to fight back. There are a few types of PVP in Dragon Nest which I will describe quite simply. There is Ladder, Endless, 1v1, and blacklisted 1v1.
Ladder is what many players might call 'competitive' mode with a rating, but in reality, it is simply an infestation of a single class. Gear plays a role in this mode and for many PVP'ers, no one actually cares about it, since gauging it as a metric of skill is completely stupid.
Endless is simply 8v8 combat. Given its playercount, it is easily the laggiest mode for many players and, simply put, is a mind-less cesspool of high AOE skill-spamming. Gear does not matter.
1v1 is what it is. Gear does not matter.
Blacklisted 1v1 is different from what you might expect it to be. To give it a bit of a background, many players view some skills as overpowered compared to other skills (example: A mercenary's 'Iron Skin'). Most classes have a few of these skills and players will mutally agree to not use these skills. For some players, Blacklisted 1v1 might include entire classes or very specific rulesets and for many players, what is blacklisted to someone might not be blacklisted to the other. Most 'legitimate PVP'ers' play this.

One other 'important' aspect about PVP is PVP rank. PVP rank is arguably important because there is an icon associated with your rank. Initially, it is a brown egg icon next to your name. As you PVP more, you get more experience and the icon changes. The other icons are blue (silver) and yellow (gold). However, be warned, the blue and yellow icons are EXTREMELY difficult to attain as they are exclusive to a certain rising XP threshold. It is difficult to describe in words but simply put, if you were to attempt to become the player with the #1 amount of experience, it would easily take you a year of pvp'ing to get even close to it.

Sound:
The sounds of Dragon Nest are fairly average I would personally say, although, one of the key issues many players seem to have is that the voice-actors for some of the classes are borderline cringeworthy, prompting some users to completely disable the voice or download a foriegn language voice mod. Another one of the issues and to many players and advantage is that most if not all the skills have their own special voice-line for casting that spell. This means when your Adept (that's a class) casts Inject, every single time you are going to hear what sounds like a child say, This might sting a bit!"

Graphics:
The graphics are good and fantastic for many of the skills. However
date: some classes and raids (nests) in particular have crippling effects on many player's computers. One class in particular
hoursPlayed: has a few spells that are strong in PvP simply because for many players
voteText: casting it is 'like opening six movies at the exact same time'
helpfulPercent:
resulting in a crippling half-second burst of lag.

Community:
The community of Dragon Nest is fairly odd. A mix of Anime fanatics and normal people coupled with a loud creepy population. The population seems to be a mix of 12 to 19 year olds with some guilds greatly skewing this margin. I highly recommend finding a guild that suits your playstyle rather than joining one of the ones that you get invited to right off the bat. The best way to do that is make a friend in-game and try their guild.

Server & Game Issues:
The server occasionally seems to have frustrating issues with lag. Sometimes these issues are extremely frustrating as they might completely void and entire 'nest'
votesHelpful: leading to a player missing out on loot. One of the most notable issues is the completely unavoidable 'Hackshield'
votesTotal: and instant kick from the game resulting in the failure of the games anti-cheat. It is not detecting a false-positive
votesFunny:
merely it just messes up.

Pay-to-win Factor:
Suprisingly
commentsCount: this game isn't nearly as pay to win as I expected. The only pay-2-win'ish factor seems to be Dragon eggs and
column16: even then
column17: the only good thing that comes from them is wings which boost your characters movement speed in everything but PVP. When it comes to costumes
column18: 'green' costumes boost stats which can pretty much only be purchased through NX (real life money). However
column19: 'blue' costumes which boost stats much greater than 'green' costumes can only be reliably purchased through large amounts of ingame gold.\n\nOverall: The game is suprisingly good but has a good few problems that detract from some of the good parts. The game seems to have a large issue when it comes to grinding of either money or levels. There are minor issues with the community regarding it's vocal immature side."

reviewText:
For some clarification: I have played this game since Open Beta around September 2011, long before it was released on Steam so I'd average around maybe 5,000 hours give or take a thousand.

This game used to be the greatest thing since sliced bread. The combat is phenomenol, still kind of is. The story is gripping although a little trope-y. Most if not all of the classes are unique in their own way, each having their own playstyle. Now why would I not recommend this game despite all the good things, it's only because the cons heavily outweigh the pros.

Let's start with content. Content is one of the biggest concerns I have had with this game for a while. The level caps have increased from 16, 24, 32, 40, 50 etc., with each cap including a couple of small 'nests' which are more or less instances with 4-5 bosses with some mechanics built in, a raid which is essentially like the nests only with 8 people instead of 4 and then the hell raid which adds a couple mechanics and makes everything stronger. Each cap lasts about 5-8 months with the exception of 40 cap which lasted nearly a year and some odd months. These months are filled with grinding the same dungeons and 'nests' week to week to try to get the best gear.

Now we'll talk about gear. Gear follows a familiar rarity system, Normal, Magic, Rare, Epic, Unique, and Legendary. Normal to Rare is highly disregarded when playing Dragon Nest, if you're seen wearing them you'll be kicked from a party without hesitation, but we'll get into community in a bit. Epic gear is obtained from doing the nests over and over again for materials to craft. There's usually 2 different Epic sets for each cap, one being for magic-based classes, the other being for physical based classes. Unique gear is obtained from completing the normal raid and getting it dropped randomly. Legendary gear is recieved from drops in the hell version of a raid. Essentially to get the best gear in the game you essentially have to just have immense luck, and not to mention a team which can actually clear a raid consistently.

Gear does not change any part of attire except for your weapons, so if you're looking to be a fashionista without forking over some cash you're out of luck. When it comes to making your character not look like the average joe, you'll usually have to pay 15-30 dollars on a costume. A lot of the time you won't be able to mix-and-match costumes to get the ultimate" look just based on the fact that you'll lose a set bonus. These set bonuses get better the more you pay up
date: and if you ever do feel the need to mix-and-match you'll have to get lucky buying gachapon and getting the single item that allows you to do so
recommended: did I mention you need one for each piece of equipment you wish to alter? That's not all
hoursPlayed: if you're looking to get the highest rarity costumes you'll need to fork over even more cash to get sets and fuse those set pieces together for a CHANCE at a higher rarity costume piece. Good luck!\n\nClass balancing is another of the bigger concerns with the game. Every so often there's a balancing patch
voteText: when this patch comes around there will ALWAYS be that one class that excells over all the others. This a lot of the time leads to people completely shunning other classes based on their tier list. And when it comes to nerfing a class
helpfulPercent: the nerf will just be making another class significantly more powerful than the other. If you're thinking about exclusively playing one class and still being able to join up with others then I'm sorry to say that's not the case.\n\nLet's get to talking about the community. It's a fairly small game so the community is kind of scrunched up. A lot of the people are generally really nice
votesHelpful: but when it comes to actually playing the game
votesTotal: personalities may be a bit skewed. A fair bit of players
votesFunny: especially the people who have been around for a long while
commentsCount: which make up a fair portion of the game
column16: are elitist in one way or another. There is a list of requirements for joining parties ranging from having proper gear
column19: etc. It doesn't matter if you're trying to learn how to do the latest nest or something to that extent
column20: you will be kicked on the spot if the party leader is not appeased by your gear. This game is without a doubt not friendly to new players
column21: I hate to say.\n\nPVP is one of the few things this game has left to offer
column22: and even in that case PVP has had an incessive lag since the game was released till now.\n\nI could keep going on and on about all the problems with the game
column23: but I feel I've covered the bare essentials. A couple years ago I would've recommended this game
column24: but unfortunately it just fell into the usual Korean MMO loop of unfortunate cases."

reviewText:
*A LENGTHY REVIEW*
Background Information:Dragon Nest is a free-to-play fantasy MMORPG published by Nexon NA (Steam Version).

Play Style/Game PlayIt uses a non-targeting combat system (which most MMORPG have), so basically you have full control of the players movement using the keys W
hoursPlayed: D". You are able to use your skills using the short cut keys "1-10" or change your key bindings to see which better suits you. Dragon nest consists of 2 game modes or 2 of both
voteText:
PvP and PvE. You start off as PvE but later through the levels you can change to PvP or do both. The game consists of 8 Characters of which they have their own unique skills and abilities.

ClassesClasses have 'specialisations' where they can change into their first and second job and focus on that particular area of combat. Specialisations are granted at level 15 and level 44.
The 8 classes include:
Warrior
Archer
Cleric
Sorceress
Tinkerer
Kali
Assassin
LanceaFor more information of the classes and what specialisations they have go to the Nexon website @ http://dragonnest.nexon.net/guides/class-guide

Like every game they have their pros and their cons. Here are mine:
Pros:
+Gameplay system. The choice of movement and mechanics are great
+Community. Everyone is nice but you do get the occasional person that isn't so nice
+Exp rate. There are so many opportunities you get with bonus exp to level up your character as fast as possible
+Simple. Easy to learn but takes practice to learn the mechanics of the characters. Practice makes perfect

Cons:
-The lack of designing your character. The class you choose has already determined of what type and style you are. You don't really have that much of a choice to change your personal features
helpfulPercent: and the gender has been set to that class.\n-Repetitive. The game can get a little repetitive at times
votesHelpful:
doing the same dungeons over and over again. But it isn't really that much of a bother if you have a friend to play with you

Overall
I've played Dragon Nest when it was in Beta
votesTotal: but I've kept quitting and coming back 3 times. I've finally stuck with the game. Leveling can be hard at times and you have no choice but to the grind to get to the level you desire
votesFunny: but that's with most MMORPGs. When I reached the level cap
commentsCount: I thought it was worth all the hard times of grinding. You'll think that reaching the max level will be the end
column16:
but it's a whole new chapter and there are far more things to do and goals to be set.

Here's my friend's guide for leveling:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=472939421

tl;dr. it's good.

Feel free to add me or ask me any questions in the comments!
"

reviewText: If you're looking for a really fast action MMO, then this is the game for you. It starts off a bit slow but once you select your first class specialization(ie. Warrior-->Barbarian, Mage-->Fire Mage) the game becomes much more intense. The combat is easily the highlight of this game; the feeling of decimating a battlefield with 30 enemies on screen with a giant AoE attack is great! I only feel the character customization is lacking... Options for hair and faces feel limited and classes are gender-locked, so if you want to play as a male Archer, you're outta luck. Overall it's a pretty solid MMO with plenty of dungeons to try your hand at.\n\n4/5

reviewText:
Overall a very fun game. However playing solo can be quite boring sometimes so it's best if you get someone to join with you.

As with all games there are pros and cons, the most annoying cons I have found are the gender locked classes, and that certain cash items have to be bought with NX Prepaid (using cards etc.) not with NX Credit (using your credit/debit card and steam cash). Other than that the game is quite enjoyable, and isn't entirely a p2w game like most so called f2p games are.

As for PVP, pretty much anyone stands a chance at being good no matter what character they have, it all comes down to skill. Though according to various forums some classes are better than others, but I disagree as I have watched so called OP classes get absolutely destroyed by the so called lower PVP classes.

The quests and levelling system can be quite grindy and repetitive at times, but if you're with a friend you dont really mind quite as much since you clear the dungeons quite quickly, most of the time in under 5mins.

I highly recommend this game for anyone to try. I was quite sceptical to begin with but have quickly become addicted to playing.
voteText: 38 of 41 people (93%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What is this game
Dragon Nest is a Free to Play MMO Action RPG with an anime-like art style. This game features fast paced combat, skill shot/aiming mechanics and 8 different classes. Unlike WoW or many other MMOs, the game isn’t open world, and most of everything is instance based.

Classes
Assassin: Deadly martial artist that deals burst dmg. Builds Str and Agi.
Shinobi: Focuses more on dealing phys dmg.

Taoist: Focuses more on supporting allies with Light and Dark powersKali: Spiritual dancer that debuffs enemies and supports allies. Builds Str and Int.
Dancer: Focuses more on dealing damage.

Screamer: Focuses more on debuffing and buffing.Sorceress: Female mage class that deals magic damage (Duh). Builds Int.
Mystic: Focuses more on Dark and Light spells/dmg.

Elementalist: Focuses more on Ice and Fire spells/dmg.Warrior: Melee sword fighter. Builds Str and Vit.
Swordsman: Focuses on slash attacks.

Mercenary: Focuses on knocking down enemies.Archer: Elf ranged bow class that focuses on dps (Duh). Builds Agi.
Sharpshooter: Focuses on single target dps.

Acrobat: Focuses on aerial combat.Cleric: Holy magic class that buffs allies and heals them. Builds Str and Vit.
Paladin: Focuses on tanking up allies

Priest: Focuses on healing allies.Tinkerer/Academic: Jack of all trades class. Builds Agi and Int.
Engineer: Focuses on doing physical damage with robots and guns.

Alchemist: Focuses on doing magical debuffs and supporting allies.Lencea: Spear/lance user thats not in the NA version as of the beginning of January 2015. Builds Str and Int.

Why did I start playing
A friend suggested that I and another friend should try this game out since he previously played it back in 2012. So I installed it, thinking it would one of those F2P games that I would play for 20 hours and stop playing. My friend had a Sorceress from before and my other friend made a Tinkerer, so I decided to make an Assassin. I specialized him to Taoist, leveled him to 20, and got bored with him. I saw that the Tinkerer can summon a giant robot and hit things with a giant wrench, which reminded me of Max from Dark Cloud 2, so I made one. When I got to choose a Job Specialization, my friend had previously made his an Engineer, so I made mine an Alchemist. This is when I really dove into the game, finding out that most of the Alchemist’s abilities are really fun to use. At level 45, I got to choose a second job specialization; the Adept’s increased Fire and Ice power or the Physician’s increased Poison and Healing power. I chose Physician because I like playing healers. Now I have 350+ hours in the game and probably not stopping soon.

Why do I like this game
I like it mainly because it’s an action RPG with fast-paced fighting and I love action RPGs. This game is not a freemium at all and very little pay to win(costume items give very little stats, and you can buy item protection jellies and revives with real money).

Why should/shouldn’t you play it
While the gameplay is fun, I have many problems with it.

Bandwagoning: Raid parties tend to favor certain classes/specs over others and instantly kick the ones that are not meta. My main class, Physician is one of those non-meta classes and I have trouble finding parties since people favor Light Bringers over Priests and Physicians. This is due to the whole “Light Party” meta that is pretty much centered around Light Bringers, Crusaders/Inquisitors and Light converted DPS classes.

Bad model textures: The textures in my opinion are low quality and unappealing.

Annoying voices: 80% characters in the game have very cheesy lines.

The Tinkerer is a 11 year old girl: The Tinkerer is commonly referred as the “Loli Class,” and the fact that I main one makes me feel like a pedo. I just like their skillset that’s all.
There many reasons why I feel people don’t play this game. First is the anime-esque art style, since a lot people dislike anime. Second is that the graphics’ quality is bad. Third is the niche community of mostly otakus and weeaboos.

Overall what do think
I really enjoy this game. I find the gameplay fun and interesting with a high amount of replay value. I would suggest people to at least try it out to see if you like it or not. This is a good game to delve into if you are bored, so I pretty much recommend this for people to play.

reviewText: The graphics are adorable. The dialog of your character and the NPCs is hilarious. There are plenty of powerful and dazzling skills to spam. There are a huge number of quests to complete. You can journey through the game solo or with friends - I REALLY like games that give you both options. All in all, this is a very fun MMORPG that does a good job of combining pure action and RPG elements. It may take a bit of practice at first to get the hang of it but give it a chance and you won't regret it.

reviewText: There's something about Dragon Nest that sets it apart from Nexon's other major action-MMO title Vindictus. It certainly has the anime style charm to it and tons of humor behind many of its characters and quests. but I feel its easier to immerse myself into the game as a whole. The combat is fun and the while the classes are genderlocked you don't really mind that fact once you start playing. I will always come back to this game when I want my fill of hack and slash adventure!

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is an instance-based action RPG playing much like an arcade game with no targeting, a strict class tree, a less strict skill tree, and more or less no character customization whatsoever. For instance, all Tinkerers are time-travelers who somehow turned into adorable lolitas, and all Kalis are abundantly female spirit dancers with sweet, slightly shy temperaments and dead masters.

Masters in their tribal ninja teachings, not BDSM masters. Moving along.

Dragon Nest's English localization is -incredibly- well-done, with dialogue that is not only legible but actually full of character and humor. The voice acting is goofy, but in a way that lines up with the character in question. The child king is nasally and distinctly lacking a courtly presence, while the storage NPC constantly complains about the horrible things other people / you leave in storage. The marketplace NPC will insult you for being poor (regardless of how much money you are holding because he's so damn rich.)

Dungeons have multiple difficulty settings, and the baddest ♥♥♥ dungeons are the titular Nests (though not necessarily dragon nests.) Abyss is the fourth and highest difficulty of any other dungeon, but it is the first difficulty of a Nest, and most of them have a Hell or Hardcore one that's much much harder than that. Nests are effectively your chokepoints for progress through the game, and at any given time one or more Nests will be the endgame" dungeon. The catch is
date: you can only /win/ one given Nest a limited number of times every week. You can fail as many times as you want
recommended: but the great majority of items from Nests are only acquired after a successful clear.\n\nSadly
hoursPlayed: despite its charms

It's basically an online arcade game.\n- It is possible to miss content. This is usually something trivial such as a non-title achievement

reviewText:
I was looking for a new MMO that had fun and challenging PvP and most of all, a story to really IMMERSE myself in. That is what gets me hooked on a game. I made the awful mistake of summing up this MMO with many J/KRPGs out there. I think most of these have very cliched story lines or have poorly written scripts. But Dragon Nest is not the case. If you're a fan of reading quests and PVP, this is definitely a game to try.

The story begins differently for each and every class you choose. Granted, they fit into the typical anime character archtypes, the boy who never gives up, the mysterious and talented but silent hero. However, their stories are interwoven in such a way that the characters interact somewhat differently with the NPC dialogues, making it interesting for different perspectives on the main story quest line.

As for the state of the game, the devs and GMs seem to pay attention and have interest in retaining their population as well. Spontaneous events occur that you simply click on and teleport to an instance for all sorts of strange games, some familiar and fun with great rewards at the end. The community seems to be tight knit, and the servers swell every time a new content pack is released, and then over the course of two months, dwindles back to a steady population. This is common and expected for most themepark" type MMOs such as WoW as opposed to "sandbox" types like EVE online.

The gameplay is very fluid
date: and each class has a large array of flashy skills that make watching their animations very enjoyable every single time. Learning combinations and stacking them is highly addicting. The only thing that feels a bit weird is jumping
recommended: there is a very slight pause before taking off from the ground
hoursPlayed: but this is probably intended this way for fairness in PVP. In a game like Dragon Nest
voteText: bunny hopping could be an issue especially with melee classes.\n\nMODS! There are mods for this game from intricate skins to voice packs. In most youtube videos
helpfulPercent: you often hear the characters in the Korean / Japanese voice overs. Admittedly
votesHelpful: I installed a Japanese voice pack and mixed it up with Korean as well. I understand neither of the language. But the game sounds MUCH better. The dialogue and the quests are completely in English. Even the cutscenes will not be a problem as they are completely captioned. It gives a more arcade feel to the game.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: Dragon Nest is a game that is definitely worth playing and worth recommending. Given Nexons track record on their game development
votesFunny: I feel that Dragon Nest is one of their better games and I hope the community grows and Nexon continues to support Dragon Nest. With its addition to steam
commentsCount: a steady influx of new players decide to give this game a try. It's very newb friendly if this is a beginning MMO for you
column16: and free to play. Give Dragon Nest a shot!"

reviewText:
Finding a random party can be kinda hard so it is recommended to play with friends. However with different starting points for every class trying to play as different classes with your friends can become an issue but you will find yourself back with your buddy in a while.
The classes are genderlocked so if you want to play as a archer or a magic caster you will have to play as a girl or if you want to play as the cleric or sword-wielder you will have to play as a guy. (Most people including myself don't see this as a huge issue but is worth mentioning.) Classes do have multiple paths depending on your playstyle.
So far the levels/dungeons feel easy even on the highest difficulty with little penalty for dieing. (however I haven't played in a while so I could be wrong or updates could have changed things.)
Despite these flaws the game is fun and is worth trying with your buddies ( It's free it's not as if you're going to lose anything besides sleep trying it out.)

reviewText:
Edit: It seems the developers of this game have really sped up the update pace, which is good and slightly alleviates some of the issues.

While it's combat is great and it sure did have a lot of potential as a game and is even actually enjoyable when things are fresh, it's not something I'd recommend playing in the long run if you're looking for something to invest a decent amount of time into. This is due to quite a few reasons, the combat is great and there was/is potential but the game has fell short in literally anything that isn't combat since release and continues to do so with no signs and a incredibly small chance of ever being fixed.

Lets start off with a few issues

-Lag is common

-PvP is not balanced and never will be most likely
-PvE is not balanced and never will be most likely

-New classes always eclipse previous ones and are overpowered in one way or another in order to promote new characters and purchases of costumes and other things for these new characters (A trend common in F2P titles). The community also supports this (Goes along with it IE: Bandwagonning,etc) and will not allow you to join parties if you're playing a class that isn't as good as some of the others sometimes.

-RNG is HUGE in this game and very good at screwing you over with it (Probably in part to get you to pay for items you need to safely enhance gear instead of investing large amounts of time in getting gold just to try again)

-Sub classes of each main class usually change from which one is best to again, promote buying class change scrolls and what not for money.

-The graphics are worse than something from 2005 and the game is not optimized at all or something is totally broken. Even with current hardware don't expect 60 fps, it's always been like this.

-A lot of the really nice purchasable things like mounts, wings, weapon skins and other things are only obtainable by dragon eggs. It's like a gachapon/lottery with a really small chance to get the items that are actually worth anything, usually you just get junk. Eggs aren't cheap either, $1.50 per single Egg and $30 for a 30 pack. You might not even get one of the good things you hoped for by spending that much either, there's people who pay hundreds to get certain items.

Now none of this is the main issue with this game nor are these all the issues. I'd say the main problem with this game is the roots of it, the way the game is designed. The game is instanced based with town world hubs. You have dungeons with monsters and a boss at the end and nests/raids which you can do a certain amount of times a week.

-Dungeons are useful for leveling up till cap.

-Nests are useful for getting drops towards crafting gear and other things.

-Raids are for end game gear, there's also a hardcore version.

-Dailies can be done once you reach cap, dailies consist of doing the current cap dungeons in order to get certain items that are useful.

So here's the deal, level caps come with
1) Filler content (Constant class rebalancing and fixes that never actually fix anything and just shift power for money)
2) A new set of dungeons
3) New nests and raid for each cap
4) A new class
You'll get one good update every 1~3months with others being nothing special (Subject to change of course, I no longer keep up with the update pace/quality as of recently)

So.. here we go, you put so much effort and time into content which is not fun for more than a week at most in order to be able to be strong enough to enjoy the new good content that comes out every 1~3months. This content is usually fun for a week at most (Excluding raids which take more time to master/beat through typically). You do dailies every single day (if you can stand doing them), nests every week (that are boring once you've learned them which takes about a week because it's literally doing the same thing every time you do them over and over which goes for any content released in this game) and the same applies to raids after a bit too. You also grind dungeons for drops, maybe grind some other various things the game has for gold and that's.. it. The game itself is fun, the combat is good and all that but all you're doing in the game is the same thing over and over and over every day in order to gear up which takes time just so you can enjoy and participate in the end game raids. There's nothing else to do, it's all instance based and not open world so you're doing this or afking.. It's just.. a shame, it's not worth your time. You'll have fun at first but by the end of it the boring, repetitive, and chore like content you need to do to get strong every day and week heavily outweighs the fun you'll have with new fresh content.

Again, this is only the main flaw and only a flaw to those who aren't playing the game casually, there's a million other problems to this game stacked on top of it that I haven't mentioned aside from how static it is. There's better stuff out there to enjoy and Black Desert is coming too which has potential. If you're looking to play a game and enjoy/invest your time in it and have fun (The reason most people play games in general), this isn't for you. It's a great game to casually play though as the combat really is just that good.

~Person who's played this game since close to the initial release

reviewText: Spent a lot of hours playing this with my girlfriend, been too long since I last played but I highly suggest. Great game, lot of fun played with a party, less fun playing alone but still a good experience for anyone who likes RPG games. The combat is probably my favourite thing about the game, real-time action and a lot of moving around and dodging. The graphics are still really good and can run on older computers with no problem. The only critique I can make, as well as being an aspect that I really like and something unique about the game is the session-based arenas in which all combat takes place. On one hand I quite like having them in sessions and having a set objective and path each time, but it becomes repititive if you have to complete several quests over some levels in the exact same area. I do, however, enjoy having to master each location and looking at different ways on dealing with the mobs/bosses. Overall, if I ever get the time/companions to play this game again, I totally would. 10/10 fun.

reviewText:
If you want to get into a free to play mmo, this is the one to play. It has the action combat and storyline of a single player rpg, with the social mechanics of an mmo.

EDIT: don't let my game time throw you off, I played this game a bunch before it came to steam.

Pros:
-Great combat
-Unique graphics/art style
-Fun NPC dialogue with some good voice acting
-Challenging bosses with selectable difficulties (which offer better rewards when completed at the higher difficulties)
-Good Variety of classes
-decent party/guild/social system
-nice soundtrack
-interesting, followable story line
-plent yof sidequests and events
-satisfying character progression
-Not pay to win! Cash shop weapons/armor generally do not provide stats, only cosmetics
-semi-complex crafting system

Cons:
-Can be a little grindy in certain level gaps (eg 18-24)
-Gender locks on classes
-not a huge variety when it comes to character custimization without paying for cash shop items
-not open world (I prefer open-world mmos, but that is just my opinion. this game would have a lot of potential issues if it was open world)

reviewText:
The Good:
-The best combat system of any RPG I've ever played. The system involves having an abundance of awesome skills at your disposal and several fighting game mechanics. The system is perfect for creating a ton of different combos that flow together very nicely.
-Leveling up is always rewarding. Not only will you see very noticable differences in your performance with new gear, new skills are unlocked frequently.
-While the class selection may appear small at first, each class branches out into 2 paths twice. So with the current 6 classes available, that's really like having 24 classes.
-Each class feels unique. This includes the classes that are made from branching out. Lunar Knights and Gladiators may both be Swordsmen, but the only similarity between the two will be a couple of basic skills and their character model.
-PVP has a great amount of variety. You can join a 1 on 1 lobby to fully experience the fighting game mechanics, you can participate in hectic 16-player team deathmatches, free-for-alls, and kill the other team's leader" matches
date: or you can play the ghouls mode
recommended: which is a standard zombie mode that functions well as a completely level-free form of PVP.\n-Higher-level PVE and PVP demand a high amount of skill from players.\n-Leveling up is mostly painless. There will be patches of grinding you'll do here and there
hoursPlayed:
but the grinding in this game is much less repetitive than in other RPGs.
-Every skill you are given has a purpose. There are very few skills that become obsolete.
-Tons of stat builds to choose from.
-The voice-acting is full of personality when it's there. Voice-acting is most prevalent during combat

and guild buffs.

reviewText:
This game is great, I've got more than enough game time to prove that. The classes proved a refreshing twist on MMORPGs that many others fail to achieve. The combat is exciting and stylish on every class in both PvE and PvP even with unbalancing on classes. The story line is pretty interesting, if you decide to even pay attention to it. However this game is not without its fair share of flaws. I'll make a small list to explain some of the more pressing problems

1. This IS a Nexon game, which if you know from their other games they treat the Chinese version of the game MUCH better.
2. Stamina system, again another Nexon thing. Once you hit the (current) cap the game drains you stamina (called PWR here) in as little as two or three dungeon runs
3. Juggling dominates PvP. You can find rooms that let you burn your PWR for medals known as chill" rooms so it is not as big of a problem as the two above

This game is worth playing. However expect to be treated like crap by the customer support and just Nexon all together. It offers a great experience to both new and old MMORPG players."

reviewText:
It's like COD, except not first person, not a shooting game, doesn't have dlc, is completely free, and isn't a rehashed pile of sh*t.


Being serious though, it truly is a pretty good game. Sure, the difficulty is p*ss easy until some end-game raids, and running the same dungeons over and over can get a little repetitive, but if you like mmorpgs with very flashy abilities, this is a great game. I remember reading once that the Alchemist class has an ability with so many flashing lights, it tends to crash people's computers (it then got blacklisted from many PvP tournaments). There isn't any real need to spend real money, as there are no pay-walls and the 'special' gear is mostly just cosmetics. I wouldn't recommend it for everyone, but it is free-to-play, so all you're really losing is your time (which I think is well spent, as it is always fun pummeling monsters). Another really nice thing is that the story is actually really interesting. Each character has their own story line too, and my personal favorite is the Assassin one, which has to do with time travel, though I won't spoil it.


My one problem with this game is that too few clothes are worn. But some people would consider that a plus.

reviewText:
Cons:
-RNG on RNG gearing system makes gearing difficult and time consuming
-People who treat the game like a job neglect new players
-Your tickets will be answered within 1-5 years (Literally)
-Game has had past troubles balancing classes and gameplay
-Can get repetitive and requires much grinding
-Gender locked classes with limited customization
-Early game leveling ends up being mostly soloed and everything is end game based
-An often lack of communication in what the game wants: may be hard for new players to get used to
Pros:
-Brilliantly fun fast paced action combat system
-A rather kind community overall, with exceptions as always.
-Challenging skill based PvP
-A wide range of classes to choose from
-Fast paced leveling
-A very manga plot if you're into that
-Not Open world (It is instance based); which I like but can be a turn off for others
-Interesting mechanics that require the players to learn the battle's ins and outs
-Always something new to get excited about
-Easy to get sucked in for all eternity

I'd like to say, for those salty over Mists of Peril the update wasn't a shock, really. I was actually grossly excited about T5 finally fixing all the issues: the class discrimination, the elemental party imbalances, and I even like the new UI after I finally got used to it. I will miss the old content, as some of it I never got the chance to enjoy, but what can anyone really do?
T5 was a long overdue update and altogether I think T5 has improved the game,
except RNG on RNG. But I don't think that'll ever get fixed.

You can expect an action MMORPG, with a not quite as in-your-face 'give us money' campaign as compared to a lot of other free MMO's. If you hold vanity as a need you'll see a lot more difficulty on that front, as well as if you treat the game like a job and need the best of everything.
You can do end game content with a little effort without putting money in, but some people will always have a stick up their bottom trying to be better than everyone else. The game will be work if you do that though.

What makes me adore the game is and always has been the combat though.
It is unlike anything I've had the pleasure to enjoy in other games.
As a veteran player whose put over 100 hours into the steam version, and at least 300-500 hours prior to getting the game on steam, I recommend the game, with all its troubles.

reviewText: Great Game when it came out, now not so much. It was innovative and kind of first of its kind. The only problem I have with DN and the main reason I stopped playing it is- I felt lonely. DN is a race to the top kind of game. It wasn't like that in the beginning but slowly became that. Everyone is racing to the top/cap and then after a while you've got newbie towns that become an absolute desert, and you've got no one to do instances with. The only time those towns become populated again is when they release a new character. If you play this game with friends, then it'll be a fun game to play and I'd recommend it. However, if you're thinking about coming in by yourself, then I'd say don't bother. It'll be fun at first, but you'll eventually feel lonely and will stop playing. DN is also a highly competitive game. If you don't have a gaming mouse, don't even step into the arena.

I would like to start off by saying that this is a wonderfully thought out game. I admire the movesets and fighting system. The graphics are nice and all.

The game feels empty despite dungeons and quests-
The lack of attack versatility beyond the few attacks makes it start to feel repetitively linear-

I wish I could get myself to play this and like it for longer than whatever my play time is, but despite playing every character and trying all of their initial movesets and the secondary moveset of the warrior.

Leaving me still saying: Empty.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is a game from Nexon, the evil minds behind Maple Story.

This game plays very much like Vindictus with various tiers of difficulty in each mission area, different loot, different bosses/moves/hp imcreased, etc. The thing that separates this from Vindictus is the cuteness of it all. This is a very cute" game where everything is nice and bright and the conversations you have with NPC's are downright funny quite often. You never know what they'll end up talking to you about before you accept a quest or are just improving relations with them.

You can pick a few different classes but they are all gender locked. A fighter is male and a sorceress is female for example.

This game is hard to describe if you haven't played Vindictus because that game has very similar ....everything! It's just a tad more.

You can crafticular mission area and so on.

It's worth trying this game just to see if you like it. I often sit down intending to do just one mission or two and end up playing for hours. Definitely the sign of a good game."

reviewText:
1. 7 classes with dynamic, purely skilled based combat...HOWEVER many classes are nerfed to the point of uselessness, so join the bandwagon classes or enjoy playing alone. Parties seek specific classes/will not play with specific certain classes so do your research first. Unbalanced class system. This applies to both PVP and PVE, but mostly to PVE. PVP is awesome and absolutely skill based, with equipment not so much [they nerf equipment to balance the playing field a little, better equipment is still advantageous].

2. Plenty of guilds/active player base... HOWEVER they're not the cream of the crop people, there are nice players but more than half the time you'll deal with immature ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that devote a bit too much time [and real life money, with microtransactions reaching several hundred dollars] on this game. That being said, if you're looking for VERY active people to regularly play with, this is the right game.

3. Free to play entirely... HOWEVER the microtransactions does give VERY NICE boosts in-game. For example, end game you might have.. 800k HP. But with a $30 costume, you can have 900k HP without having to buy expensive gear. Costumes can also boost your movement speed [some classes are SLOW AS HELL], which is kind of nice. Some costumes are really cool, like robotic wings... or a dragon mount/pet... even fun things like a fluffy sheep.

4. Unbelievable amounts of grinding, there's no way to avoid this. You can buy powerlevels, have fun with that. Grinding for max level then for decent gear, because the bosses hit HARD and unless your skills can avoid the bills, keep farming that gear. Also when partying with people they won't even play with you if you have bad gear... so YOU BETTER GRIND.

5.  Speaking of #3 and #4, microtransactions can be used to.. avoid grinding for money a bit. You can buy items with real life money, and sell in game for gold.

6. Noncombat skills available, just not purely combat oriented. HOWEVER ... 3 skills: cooking, fishing, farming. No one fishes/fishing is completely useless. Cooking is likewise the same and the ingredients for cooking are so weird/hard to obtain that it's not worth it [have to rely on RNG drop rates, not gathering]. Farms are overpacked/almost impossible to obtain farm spots unless you can acquire a few spots and obsessively watch over your spot so no one else takes it.

7. Great story lines.

Okay, I'm just gonna start listing ♥♥♥♥ right off the bat here.

-Pros.
The combat is well executed, as to have reflex-based combat, instead of targeting, as do most other RPG's have that.
Customization was okay, would have preferred there to be a bit more variety, armor wise, though.
Excellent storyline, probably the best thing about this game.
Animations for the skills are cool as hell to watch, as well as the skills themselves. Speaking of skills, very wide choice of skills, and specializations for your desired class.
Graphics are brilliant, very well drawn, and simple. The way they should be.

-Cons.
REALLY, REAAALLLLYYY grind-esque experience, most of the game I was either grinding my character to the cap level, {which they are ALWAYS, changing.} Or, I'm paying others gold to boost me to those said higher levels.
Game speed isn't always the best, as it likes to lag a LOT, It might just be me, though. Eh, who knows.
Good variety of class choice, but they're genderlocked, so -1 for customization.
The very buggy, and annoying HackShield" always seems to ♥♥♥♥ its pants at random times
recommended: and me having to reinstall Dragon Nest. Multiple times

reviewText:
Now, the veterans can defend this game all they like, but I started playing the game around the day that the infamous level 90 patch came out so let me release a review from the viewpoint of a new play who has reach level 75 and stopped playing due to immense boredom

Pros
>Combat System
-The combat system is the only thing that this game has going for it, you can pull intricate strings of combos and abilities
>Classes
-Each class is unique and awesome, I love how they all look

Cons
>EVERYTHING ELSE!
-Let me elaborate

>Any dungeons below level 90 are SUPER MEGA ULTRA..... easy

-Apparently, these dungeons USED to be difficult, but they decided to completely F***ING remove the hardest difficulties for all low level dungeons. The nests are easy when they used to require a party, (I MEAN FOR GOD'S SAKE, YOU'RE NOT EVEN ALLOWED TO PARTY FOR THE FIRST NEST) you take no damage while the enemies all die in one hit, and you can't even stumble over to higher level dungeons if you want a challenge because it's barred by a level cap, and by the time you reach the recommended level for the dungeon, it'll be too easy. I was waiting for the game to get difficult FOR 75 LEVELS. I WAS ONE SHOTTING EVERY ENEMY AND BOSS IN EVERY DUNGEON FOR 75 LEVELS! At that point, if the game can provide zero excitement for what was essentially 70% of the game, then it's not good game design. And I'm patient, oh I'm very patient, I'm always willing to give a game a chance, but this game could not impress me, it took too long.

>Story missions progress way too slowly

-I won't talk too much for this one. Basically, once you reach level 60, the dungeons that you have to traverse through for the story will have a recommended level of 45. Not to mention, really intimidating monsters appear in the story cutscenes a lot, and you end up getting excited at the fact that you'll be able to finally get a challenge, only to have your  character get stomped on in the cutscene and have the bad guy run off with the important McGuffin that you were sent to chase after and you instead have to fight some insignificant boss, that just basically ends up becoming a miniboss in later dungeons. But hey, at least there's occasional voice acting and almost every character has a unique personality why you can then elborate on through giving them gifts, but that's only fun if you're actually interested in this game's story.

>PvP is Balanced"
-Unless you're playing with friends who are around the same level as you
date: you're essentially not allowed to PvP until you're level 90. Oh
hoursPlayed: there's and equalizer put into play so that your stats are basically increased to what they would be around level 90. The problem is that your skills still do garbage damage against players who have more points put into their skill trees
voteText: have better armor
helpfulPercent: and have learned their combos while you have nothing to protect yourself with.. The equalizer just makes killing you take like 30 more seconds than it should.\n\nDon't play this game unless you have a time machine. I've heard countless good things about the game before the update
votesHelpful: all things that I wish I could've been a part of
votesTotal: but from what I can guess
votesFunny: the developers wanted to make it easier to reach level 90 to appeal to players who want have level 90 characters for all the classes
commentsCount: and for some reason they decided to remove content that didn't need to be removed in the first place."

reviewText: Traffic can be slow. Fills up fast during events and level cap raises (the lag can get pretty bad). Level cap is irritating. People usually quit/take a break not too long after they hit the current max level. Updates are slow to come. Guild system, friend list, dungeons, nests, market, drops, crafting, skill trees, the usual MMORPG stuff. Player verse player is super fast-paced and exciting. Various team modes and maps available. Characters are not very customizable and are gender-locked. Often you find yourself versing or partying up with your long lost twin.\n\nGraphics style not for everyone; anime-inspired. DN is for people who don't mind a cartoony look to their games.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is Asian made action targeting MMORPG that is free to play.

Cons:
-The classes are gender locked and no customization.
-The avatar artwork is asian style munchkins.
-The graphics are outdated.

Personally, i was Not impressed with the game enough to play more.  Need to get back to playing my games that i have paid for like LOTRO, STO, DDO, and SWTOR.

I am sure someone might like this game, give it a try.


Play Style/Game Play
full control of the players movement using the keys W
hoursPlayed: D".  Skills using the short cut keys "1-10".  Dragon nest consists of 2 game modes or 2 of both
voteText:
PvP and PvE. You start off as PvE but later through the levels you can change to PvP or do both. The game consists of 8 Characters as Classes of which they have their own unique skills and abilities.

Classes have 'specialization' where they can change into their first and second job and focus on that particular area of combat. Specialization are granted at level 15 and level 44.

The 8 classes include:
Warrior
Archer
Cleric
Sorceress
Tinkerer
Kali
Assassin
Lancer

For more information of the classes and what specialisations they have go to the Nexon website @ http://dragonnest.nexon.net/guides/class-guide

reviewText:
Dragon Nest has me questioning why I didn't get into action MMO's sooner.

The game itself has a relatively small community, but offers some awesome content and events for the players that do consistently log on. It sports some anime inspired graphics. While still giving some insanely cool and much more dark detail to most mobs and each boss at the end of every portal.

Dragon Nest starts you out in a city called Mana Ridge" which unfortunately seems like a cliche
date: because it ♥♥♥♥ing is. The game doesn't really start being eye popping until you step outside of the city and engage in your first dungeon. At that point I find you start to really appreciate the games graphical prowess and charming game mechanics.\n\nWhile being cliche with the story and theme
recommended: Dragon Nest really does well with its combat. It has you enter a portal into a certain area (think Guild Wars)
hoursPlayed: and from that you can choose one of the varied number of "runs" you can take from there; you then have 5 options for which difficulty you want to run the dungeon on
voteText: easy for chumps or abyss for MEN. If I choose abyss (which the game recommends you only do in a party of 4)

votesTotal: even though the idea isn't original
votesFunny: and even though it literally has you do the same thing over and over.\n\nThat being said
commentsCount: the game sucks in these categories.\n\nWell

column17: it was the biggest cluster ♥♥♥♥ you could imagine. It promised fluid attacks
column18: and engaging combat. What it did deliver was a trash hitbox system and incredibly out of balance classes. One lower leveled warrior could hit a stun
column19: and just slaughter people. It drew a very distinct line between PvE and PvP oriented classes. I played it again recently on a new character and while some of the before ignored issues were resolved (The hit boxes are much much better now) It just didn't have the charisma the PvE combat had and continues to seperate and distinguish classes as PvP or PvE oriented. Especially warriors. They still stomp everybody.\n\nSo

reviewText:
(Note: my steam playtime does not show my playtime with Nexon's standalone launcher from during the beta, actual playtime is around 80 hours)

With regards to the PvE content, it contains the standard MMO tropes of leveling: experience points and stat based gear progression.

The dungeons are fun, the monsters are neat, and the storyline is alright.

The varied enemy types actually do different attacks and have slightly different A.I., even between palatte swaps.  If it looks different, it behaves differently.

The cut scenes are entertaining i suppose, but its really all about combat.

Leveling does eventually slow down dramatcially, once you run out of the standard go kill everything in this dungeon" quests
date: requiring you to re-play dungeons and boss rooms
hoursPlayed: just to level up.\n\nWith regards to the actual overall character progression
voteText: its mainly about upgrading your weapons (and armor too of course).\n\nThis is where the Pay to Win comes in
helpfulPercent: but ill get to that in a minute.\n\nIf you want to upgrade an item
votesHelpful: you can minimally improve it up until level eight (the weapons level
votesTotal: not the character).\n\nEvery time you upgrade an item
votesFunny: you spend the materials to perform the upgrade.\n\nOccasionally
commentsCount: the upgrade fails
column16: meaning you lose the mats but keep the item.\n\nAfter level eight
column17: you risk several random outcomes:\nbreaking the weapon (or armor) entirely
column19: \nmerely losing your mats with no change in stats
column20:
or actually upgrading the item by one level.

The potential to completely lose your item is very real
column22: making you go back to previously played content to get a replacement
column23: which you would then need to upgrade again.\n\nSo
column24:
you can lose your item on a bad "roll" of the upgrade luck dice (metaphorical).

What can be done about this?

You can pay real money to buy "seals"
column25: which protect your item from breaking. (but not from the other potentially bad outcomes
column26: such as deleveling the item.)\n\nThe pay to win ethos permeates the rest of the game as well

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is probably one of the top 5 Free MMORPGs out there. With a top notch combat leveling system, and best in class PvP action, Dragon nest is defently a game that should be considered playing, if a fan of MMOs. The game starts you off with selecting a class of your choice and each of these classes have their own seperate main story lines that really add to the replayability. Keep in mind that these classes are gender locked and in total have 9 different options to chose from, The art style of the game is more anime and some of the NPC voice acting is hard to get through without cringing. The soundtrack is honestly top notch and when parred with the soundeffects of the game from the skills/abilities or simply basic attacking, creates an audio masterpiece. PvE inculdes a long enjoyable story sepperate for each class, alongside 100s of side quests and daily quests. PvP is extremely fun, arguably the best of all MMOs, all though, i wouldent recomend before level 35, due to most of the PvP community consists of max level charecters (90), and due to them being max level, not only do they have more experience, but they can easily trap you in a chain of attacks due to your lack of skills at a low level. Dragon nest is a heavily instansed bassed game, but if you can get passed the 5-15 seconds loading screens, this shouldent bother you. In the terms of character customisation, outside of the cash shop, your options are extremely lacking, however if you are willing to invest 5-10 dollars, you can begin to gain some freedom. On the topic of the cash shop, there are tons of options for not only costume, but actual in-game items aswell. Through steam you are able to use your steam wallet for the cash shop.

Pros:
-Top notch combat.
-Tons of content in PvE.
-Outstanding party play.
-Unique dungeons.
-Very cool combat animations.
-Dungeons rate performances.
-Competative and Enjoyable PvP.
-Main Story line differs for each class.
-Consistant art style .

Cons:
-Charecter appearence customisation is EXTREMELY lacking outside of the cash shop and micro transactions
-Gender locked classes.
-Some of the faces are just.....bad.
-No customisable UI.
-Heavily instansed bassed game.
-Cringe worthy voice acting.
-while yes there are a lot of side quests, some of them are straight up anoying.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is a fun game for those tired of tab-targetting games. It is fast paced and entertaining. I will list some of the pros and some of the cons to the game.

Pros:
-Cute chibi style animation
-Unique classes and specializations
-Live-action combat (yes you have to aim)
-Good story
-Supports different playstyles (pvp, pve elitists, and pve casuals)
-Leveling is pretty easy
-Decent ability to replay (reroll multiple characters)

Cons:
-Repetitive quests (you will have to do the same dungeon several times)
-Not new player friendly (takes a lot of getting used to as far as crafting, build guides, rotations, and how to obtain gear)
-Not very challenging until higher levels
-Cosmetics (costumes, while visually appealing, give stats and you have to pay real money for them, I am cheap so no thank you)
-Small community (good luck finding answers to your questions, most people just wing it)
-The running animation is hilarious in the worst way for all classes

When all is said and done it is a very fun game that is easy to get into but difficult to get into competitive content. I would label it more as a casual game. For a free to play game it is not pay to win, but it is pay to look better than everyone else and have a bit of an edge as far as stats if you buy costumes and pets. It may not be perfect but it is a great game to kick back with friends who are tired of playing other things.

reviewText:
I used to play on SEA server, and if I still remember correctly, Steam would put player on NA server I think?
But the review would include both perspective anyway.

Pros:
-You get to kill dragon, gotta kill them all, in a group of 8.
-you get to shoot beam from your swords, cast laser beam from the heavens, time stop people, shoot nightmarish arrows that chases people forever, launch a horde of ducks, play with Thor Hammer and even feel fabulous with lightning sparks booming around you.
-Immersive combat system for both pve and pvp, very
-Socially fun, especially with your friends IRL.

Neutral (as varies between different country servers):
-music
-character (including npc) voicing
-events (lay mostly on effort side instead of real-cash bonus side)

Cons:
-class discrimination and inbalance exists (e.g priest are more favoured in party for heals)
-hack and slashes skills does not cut through clothes
-grind-repetetive
-RNG over RNG over RNG, and effort intolerance.
-gear can be accessed into a higher level in pvp with pay2win contents.
-market inflation exists
-long loading screen throughout the world if you do not have a good spec

despite being a free MMO (as usual), I'd still say the pros overweight the cons, though I would still not recommend it to player that are planning to dedicate most of their lifetime on this one since it gradually dies down and lower the element of [social entertainment]. 6/10 would definitely solo a dragon again with dead team mates.

reviewText:
Honestly, I do not see how this game has a 'very positive' review score when compared to similar Free-to-play Action MMORPGs. First of all, the combat is very good. When you attack and kill things it has weight to it. You feel like you are striking your foes. But that is all that is good in this game.

THE BAD:

The UI is clunky and not customizable at all. You can't even see more then one action bar. You can't move UI elements to appease. These are things that should be standard in any MMO since 2003.

You can't keybind more then one action bar full of actions. 1-8 is all you can assign and you have 3 classes worth of skills. This is nonsense.

Loading screens everywhere! Join a dungeon, loading screen. Kill two groups of mobs, loading screen to next area. Kill a group of mobs, go to loading screen to next area. That is INSANE! More loading screens than a PSOne game.

Balance. The game is way, way too easy. From what I read on the forums they nerfed enemy damage and increased EXP multiplier so that you can reach level cap really fast. So people migth think that is a good thing but to me, personally, it is not. Learning the game is half the fun. Do you really want idiots that barely know how to play in PvP and in your Guild because they reached max level cap in less than a week? There is no way they know their class.

Loot at the end of the dungeon/raid is random. So it's very possible that you do a dungeon over  many, many times to get a piece of a equipment that you want. This is crazy. I had to do a dungeon 10 times before I finally got a better weapon.

Cash Shop is full of 7-day" items. You basically pay real money for temporary items. I know it's common in most Korean MMOs but this is complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. All real-money transactions should be permanantly tied to your account.

Another problem is if you go on hiatus for a month they lock your account. Don't be surprised if when you come back from vacation your characters will be gone. You have to contact support and provide detailed information to get it back. This can take up to a week and by then you probably don't want to play anymore."

reviewText: Dragon Nest is a rare gem in the vast market of free to play MMOs. The game requires dedication, but if you stick with it the game can be extremely fun. The community is wonderful, and most people are willing to help. Make sure you join a guild because they will probably be more than willing to help you out. The first guild I ever joined was willing to gear me when I reached the previous level cap ( no guild I was ever a part of in Wow would do that). I am still with that guild and glad that I have stuck with them. The only real downside to the game is the time it takes for new content to come out. If nexon would keep the US servers up with the servers in SEA that would be awesome. So, in closing I would just like to state that dragon nest is one of the best MMOs you could ever play, but be prepared to spend some time and maybe a little money (only if you want to look awesome).

reviewText: ive played this game for 4 Years and it is one hell of an rpg, commuinity is awesome players are awesome and 50/50 chance you will get help if you need it, but this game reqires dedecation i never really got the chance to talk to a dev/GM in all the time i played but i heard they are preety cool. Anyways if you are looking for an awesome rpg this is one to try out, but i must warn you, it is a pay to be able to kick ♥♥♥ in pve type of game, pay to win if you would like me to put it a better way. in this game if you want the best gear you got to be fully loaded not in cash but in gear, you have to be ready for anything the enemys throw your way and in order to increase your gear to top notch you need to spend cash so that you wont lose to the clumsy black smith who should be a pro at crafting gear . Anyways if you havent tryed this give it a try even though i wrote all of the above, give it a try it is a good game and if you like it and say to your self that you are going to dedicate your self to it, then spend cash on it ''pro tip'' leave the vanity items for last and craft your gear first. crafting your gear to 6 is free but byond that point it will break. look for the shop and buy jellys and you will be able to use that to protect your gear from breaking. oh and one last thing looks can be deciving in this game some people dont have good gear and can play very good and other look really expericed but they dont play that great so if they need help give em a hand maybe one day they will help you. teamwork is the keyin this game. 10/10 for me just wish getting jellys was much easy if you have questions about anything just send me a Message and il help you out with what i can.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is a great game when it's generous enough to let you play. I've been disconnected so many times that I've nearly given up on the whole game, which is unfortunate because when it works, it works well. Dragon Nest has lots of areas to explore and tons of baddies to spank up. There are armors and weapons aplenty and the fast paced action is a nice alternative to the plethora of point and click WOW styled MMOs out there.

If you can stomach all of the cutesy wutesy dialog and horrible 5th grader  humor, then I'd suggest giving it a shot. But, as soon as you notice the countless connection errors, go ahead and shelf this one, as it won't be getting any better...

I like games that let me play them [7/10]

reviewText:
Hello! I have to say, Dragon Nest is the only MMO that I've gotten deeply into. I've found that compared to most other MMOs, this game has a much simplier way of going about things, which is a good thing, don't worry!
The combat is very easy to grasp, and quiet enjoyable with the big flashy moves and sweet combos :)
The ingame Marketplace isn't as terrible as some people say. I personally don't have any problem with it.
Even if it seems like you get overwhelmed with the amount of quests sometimes, i.e. reaching lvl 30ish, just accept them all, and the quest menu really helps organize them, telling you how many quests per dungeon you have.
The community isn't the best in terms of finding other people who want to do the same thing as you i.e. low lvl characters looking for abyss runs, or looking for some buddies to lvl up with. Nexon could refurbish the party system to make it costumizable and have a better search engine" in game to find parties with the same interests.

The only two problems I found that I have with the game are the Arena and arriving at the Lvl cap.
The arena seems to be 90% made of lvl 60 (lvl cap) players
date: leaving no room or welcoming feeling for anybody lower than lvl 42. :( Now there are the very occasional custom games of low and mid lvls
recommended: but its only about 1-2 of those games per couple hours
hoursPlayed: if that.\nArriving at the lvl cap...I have to say
voteText: I was extremely dissapointed. First off
helpfulPercent: the game has a PWR system
votesHelpful: which is an in game "energy" system for doing dungeons. i.e. I'm lvl 30 doing a dungeon by myself
votesTotal: it will take 30 out of my 800 power for that dungeon. The amount used per person decreases
votesFunny: the larger the party is. Also if you are party with a "pupil" you are "mentoring" you don't lose any PWR for that dungeon. The PWR regenerates over time (1 day)\nBut...when you reach lvl 60
commentsCount: it uses 10x the original amount. Yeah...\nThis is what happened to me
column16: I was lvl 60 and went to go help my lvl 32 friend do a dungeon on the hardest difficulty. Once I got to the dungeon
column17: it tells me I have to use 198 PWR to do one dungeon. So in the "long run" I would only be able to help him with 5 dungeons in one day. A very large buzzkill i have to say.\nAlthough mentoring a pupil should not take any of your PWR in the dungeons
column18: this concept has no effect at the lvl cap :(\nI do understand that this 10x the amount setup is to stop 3 lvl 60s to rush a lvl 1 through the game in no time or something similar. But if this system could be tweaked
column19: it would be preferable.\nMy idea is that the mentoring system could at least cut the PWR consumption in half at the lvl cap
column20: if anything.\n\nAside from those two things
column21:
I find this game to be pretty damn kickass :D
Well those are my thoughts on this xD *looks up the page* -.- damn I wrote a novel... xD

Take care gamers! Have fun!

~Quazz~"
