reviewText:
wow, great game, and im just starting out. why play this game? ive tried countless mmos, and most follow the same pattern, click enemy to attack, sell your stuff, level up lame attacks, oh, and dont forget to occasionally get cool stuff, if you pay alot.
this mmo offers not only a variety of classes, but very smooth transitioning between quests, as well as a good map, nice interface, and awesome graphics. my only complaints are:

1. the classes are gender based. this doesnt ruin the game one bit for me, it would just be nice if perhaps i could play a male engineer, or a female assassin, or whatever opposite gender they have

2. the game can be a bit laggy in the main hub like areas, although i do play the game on a less than ideal computer, so this can also be disregarded.

3. the overall choices based on character looks are suboptimal at best, with a handful of hairdoes, colors, and eyes. though no worries as youll hardly see the face anyways, and all the few hairstyles the DO offer are pretty good looking anyways.

aside from these, i HIGHLY recommend the game. if your searching steam for a good rich, awesome class based mmo to download, take it from me whos downlaoded 20+ different ones and at least give this one a try. :o)

reviewText: I would personally like to thank this game for ruining my Christmas of 2015. The day of December 25th, I went to charge money to the game through steam and it decided that right after I authorized the charge it was going to give me an error code. I did not have time to get the error code number because this has been an issue in the past but I went after 10 minutes to check and see if my NX had been charged, and of course without a doubt it was not charged. I began to search the website looking for ways to submit a ticket or get a refund. I then found out that Nexon does not hand out refunds under ANY circumstances. Which is understandable to a certain extent. Because that it was somewhere between their services and steam's services miscommunicated, I ended up losing $20 of my steam wallet money. I will barely put anymore effort and time into this game due to that situation and due to them not being able to do anything about them basically stealing my money. Even after the purchase showed up on my steam wallet purchases. Thanks once again Nexon for taking my money and ruining my Christmas of 2015.

reviewText:
DN has gone way downhill as support for the game has weakened...


- Aside from the smooth satisfying combat (when your not lagging) the game is lacking in content and quite boring.
- Has repetitive holiday events and offers very little innovation into its genre.
- Guild support is bare-bones and quite pointless/unnecessary.
- DN is VERY punishing to new players that don't have friends to hold their hand upon arriving at max level.
- Promotes PTW.
- Very poor servers, making PvP feel like its a joke and PvE feel unfair at times (but not as often).
- Majority of the community is quite bad at the game (my opinion), making it hard for them to get with parties so they can improve. (unless they have a friend/guild willing to hold  their hand)
- NO BENEFITS for helping new players. No worthwhile rewards are guaranteed to helping new players/doing old content (this WAS shown in the form of the fledgling bonus" which gave extra drops to a players first time doing a nest
date:
it was removed)

2.5/10
tl;dr
Amazing combat
Pathetic overall execution/innovation
Bad community
Laughable servers
Very punishing to new players



-This could change with T5 but as of now not worth the time."

reviewText:
No longer recommending Dragon Nest after playing Since Aug 2011. I only recently started playing using the Steam engine which is why I only have a few hrs on record.

I usually pick up this game when there's absolutely nothing else to do with my time, but now, I see no reason to even bother logging in. The servers have always lacked stability as far as I can remember. Anyone who's played since 40 cap can tell you how bad it gets. For an MMO, it's not a BAD game, but the server stability is what ruins it for me. (More on that later)

Looking into how bad the server is, sometimes you will disconnect for no apparent reason. It could be right in the middle of a boss battle or raiding. Other times, it could be when you get a good roll on a rare drop and suddenly you get kicked from the server. This has been going on since 40 cap which was already more than 4 years past and Nexon has hardly done anything to manage this problem.

The community is more of the same. You'll meet nice people who just want to play for fun and get by and other times (mainly in PvP) you'll meet a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ elitists who think they're all that. For an MMORPG, it's nothing spectacular.

Class balance will always be an issue in the game. Even before the sub-classes came out in 50 cap, there was still class imbalance mainly in pvp.

Gearing up chars for certain classes will be heavily dependent on how popular that class is. The more higher" that class
date: the more expensive and tedious it will be. Again

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game to you if it was still 2012.

This game has turned to ♥♥♥♥ to be completely honest - and it has done so in almost every aspect thinkable. The story is boringly repetetive and cliche, the servers lag in most countries so you will teleport back and forth and not be able to hit anything, the community is pretty much non-existant and the people left are max level so they'll ignore you, the devs changed the difficulty system so you may now only play the early levels on the easiest settings, and worst of all: the game is far too easy.

It seems to have the opposite problem to most mmos, in that it's not 'grindy' or difficult, it's just running through every dungeon and killing everything a few times and then moving onto the next dungeon (It is grindy in that aspect). It feels more like a poorly made and boringly long singleplayer game that still has the lag issues of being a f2p asian mmo. Playing this is just like waiting for the ending to come, and if a game has that quality, then just go back to real life since it's the same ♥♥♥♥, but with characters that actually matter.

The only way I recommend this game is if you bring together a bunch of friends and play through it in short bursts as a party whilst not taking it too seriously. In 2012/13 you could have done this with players you met in game, but now the only community left are at max level as stated.

Base Game: 7/10
What You Get: 4/10

reviewText:
Dragon Nest is a fast paced, hack-and-slash MMORPG. I enjoy the many classes and advancements in Dragon Nest, such as the Warrior, Cleric, or Assassin! Obviously there's more than those three. Dragon Nest is almost revolutionary due to having a different fighting style, not just point and click.

Overall: I'd give it a 6.8/10. There is so much to the game already, but there can be more that could be improved.

Controls & Handling: 8/10. The controls are easy to learn, but it ranges from class to class. The Warrior is immensely faster than any other class due to unlocking the dash ability at level 10.

Graphics: 5/10. The graphics are subpar compared to other games such as Aion: Ascension or Guild Wars 2, but it gets the job done. The main point of Dragon Nest is definitely not graphics

Storyline: 8/10. The storyline is centered around your specific class saving the world, which is kind of stereotypical, but once you get into the game, it goes into the lore. Such as the  aging difference of archers/elves or how the Cleric becomes high priest of an organization. Really tedious to start, but great to read through once you've gotten interested.

Music: 6/10. The music kind of just... fits. Although, during dungeons it can be quiet until you start attacking an enemy, but once the music gets going, you really get hyped for battle and it makes you have a sense of urgency.

and Desert Dragon Nest for level 60+ . All of them are different but are all packed with intense boss fights so it requires alot of coordination and communication. reviewText:
Nexon has developed a reputation for releasing games that, while great on a gameplay level, are filled with microtransactions and alterations to the game to force you to buy them. While Dragon Nest continues this legacy to a degree, it's not as bad as other games the company has put out. From a gameplay standpoint Dragon Nest is very fun with its combo-based combat. The six classes (as of this review) are all fun to play in their own ways, and the specializations they can take let them further define their styles in unique ways. While the early levels can be a bit of a slog, once you get to around level 30 the game really opens up in terms of the skills you get. And whether your fighting alone, with a friend, or against a friend the combat is always enjoyable.

It's unfortunate then that the rest of the game around it is a little shallow. Quests are your standard affair, either go here and kill this or go here and collect this. A few quests spice things up in interesting ways such as giving you an overpowered NPC helper or giving you a unique enemy to fight, but such quests are few and far between. Thankfully if fighting AI monsters gets boring you can always fight your fellow man in PvP. PvP is fairly balanced (with a few exceptions) with an emphasis on personal skill rather than your gear and stats.

This brings me to the much despised part of any Nexon game, the cash shop. While games like Mabinogi and Maplestory are pretty much pay-to-win when it comes to their cash shop, Dragon Nest really doesn't feel that way. Sure the costumes give nice stat boosts and there are items that protect your gear from breaking while enhancing them, but such things aren't necessary unless your absolutely serious about min-maxing. Even then you should be fine as long as you invest in a decent skill build and have practiced enough to use your skills to their fullest. You even get a special level up reward box that gives out certain cash shop items like storage and inventory space, meaning you don't have to spend a dime so long as your patient.

I have a feeling alot of people have/will blow this game off just because Nexon is publishing it, which is a shame. While it has its flaws Dragon Nest is a pretty decent action game if you put some time in it. It might not be the best game ever but it certainly is leagues above some of Nexon's other games. I advise you to give it a try and at least play up till level 30 or so before you pass your final judgement on the game.

reviewText: Dragon Nest is not a normal MMORPG, it is one of the best rpg's I've ever played it doesn't use cheap auto attacking it has a real hack n' slash system in the game. It has an actual story with real cutscenes and voice acting and I find the story very interesting to follow.  I would recommend this to anyone who wants a nice new fresh experience in rpgs. reviewText: Dragon Nest is, in my opinion, an incredible game. I can't really think of anything I don't like about it, although I'm sure there's a few flaws in it, they're certainly not significant at all. The art is genuinely pleasing for an anime-style game, there's a pretty good choice of classes, with my only complaint being that they are genderlocked, but I haven't really found that to be much of a problem, personally. I like all of the dungeons and how they all have their own theme and the different difficulties are definitely a nice bonus. I find that it is also quite possible to be good at the game without spending money on it, and the Dragon Vault gives good options for character customization by allowing different durations for the equipment items, along with stats on most of them. I find Dragon Nest to be an all around amazing game, currently my favorite, and I would definitely recommend it. :)

reviewText:
It's pretty much a World of Warcraft C9/Vindictus graphics wise. C9 and Vindictus are dead, Dragon Nest is still very much alive.

The combos aren't nearly as good as C9, which makes it very newbie friendly, but at the same time the Raids are much more difficult, catering to the hardcore players.

If you give this game a shot, at least play until level 24, when you get the fun skills. When I first tried it out I dismissed it at level 12 or so because it was generic, but obviously I just didn't have any of the good skills by then.

They really did a good job distributing buffs and debuffs throughout the classes, every raid contains no multiples, and the ones that do only have one or two, making most classes desirable.

As for p2win, you can get virtually everything by grinding, which may take a bit, but it's certainly not as p2win as most other F2P titles.

The only major downside is the gender locked classes, the tinkerer looks like she's an 8 year old girl... But if you can see past that, it's most definitely one of the best games out there.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest's combat system made me realize that i probably could never play another MMO that didnt have a similiar feel to it. You dont see a move go right through a monster or player and see a -MISS- icon. The only way to miss is to have bad aim.

Be prepared to devote your life to this game, and be willing to give up your soul.

EDIT
I guess i should be a little more precise.

PROS:
Combat System: COMPLETELY INCREDIBLE. This is a 4/5 year old game, and that fact there are no target locks, and no other game that i can think of with a combat system that also DOES NOT USE target locks, makes this game stand out way above the others. If you miss, its just bad aiming, or the inevitable lag.

Story Line: Ive only played one class completely to the current level cap storyline (80 atm), and i absolutely love it. People say that MMO storylines arent the greatest, and i understand that having played few other MMOs as well, but i have to say DN has a amazing storyline (For Kali class anyways, havent branched out into other classes as much.)

Leveling: This is not a grind-cringing spending months to hit level cap. In fact, just recently they LOWERED the needed exp needed to level up per level. If you no-lifed 4 days, im pretty sure you could be level cap, or really close.

Content: The amount of content in game is enourmous, albeit alot of it are lower cap level nests and such. But the game doesnt totatlly abandon, having weekly nests to have a chance of getting level cap equipment to gear up. But the thing that kept me playing for 6000+ hours was the raids. Finding a dedicated group of 7 other people, to learn, and defeat the dragons every level cap, and finally doing it for the first time. That'll never get old.

Communtiy: Ive met alot of nice, friendly, funny people in this game. There are alot of people in here that are willing to help you, whether through tips or finding someone to leech out of (dont leech please), to make youre experience be a good one, and helping you learn about your class. I spent so much time in game, in chat systems talking to these people, theyre family to me. More so than my real life friends.

CONS:
Communtiy: The saltiest people are in this game. I swear they eat a bag of salt before they start playing everyday, thats how salty there are. But ofcourse, every community has those right? Dont be suprised to meet one. Want some help running level cap nest? If you join a party and you dont have decent gear, -permakicked from party-. But they did add diffilcutly levels to nest, so i guess it balances out..... to a point...

Latency: THIS IS THE SINGLE THING KILLING THIS GAME (Well nexon in general). DDOS on MapleStory AFFECTS DRAGON NEST BECAUSE WE RUN ON THE SAME SERVER. Why? Cant they afford dedicated servers for Dragon Nest? Im pretty sure they can from the $$$$ people spend in this game for cash shop items. Lag is so bad, it affects pvp, character skills going off when youre juggling them, getting hit by stomp mechs WHILE IN THE AIR, and just bad lag in general. I know there will always be lag, but when people start mass dcing from the world, then yea, im pretty sure its not our bad comps. Also PVP is a terrible mess. A beautiful, stunnin, bright, and at times, VERY VERY LAGGY MESS. But i digress...

Randon Number Generator(Cash Shop, Enhancing, Etc): Alot of beautiful costumes, pets, wings etc. Too bad the Random Number Generator is terrible. Want the newest wings? Buy a 30 egg pack, worth $29.90, and hope that RNGods are with you. Ive seen people spend THOUSANDS trying to get things in those eggs, myself included, and to be dissapointed in my bad luck. Want to enhance a Legendary Grade weapon to +12? Good luck grinding for the gold, to just see it gone in 1 try, that probably wont succeed anyways. With so much people spending money on this game, they should atleast compensate those who spend past a certain limit. i mean, to spend a months paycheck in one go... and to get nothing in return... yea thats definetly not worth it.

CONCLUSION
Would i recommend this game? Hell yeah, this is a awesome game, with not that bad graphics, and a incredible story line and combat system. Find the right people in game, find the right group to do stuff with, and to find a right guild to be a part of, then this game will be very enjoyable. Dont try to be a leecher, cause many people WILL ignore you, or avoid replying to you. Plan on spending on this game? Your choice, i gave you my outlook of the cash shop, but i guess if youre lucky, it wont be so bad. But ive seen so many unlucky people. But one word of advice, if youre still trying out the game, make a decision whether youre not youre planning on playing for the long term. In any game really, you should debate if youre going to or not. Would be a waste to spend $$$ just to quit a month later.

All classes has unique skills and combos.
Cash shop is aight.
Nice animations
Can see Irine's pantsu.But oh boy those cons though.
This game is one of the grindest game I have ever witnessed. I've ran the same dungeon 200 times to get from 60-70.
The game has very limited character customization in creation and makes you spend your dough to change your appearance.
Gender lock classes.
The story can get repetitive since it makes you go back to the same dungeon 10 times so people just grinds the same spot to reach a certain level.
You get very little exp from dungeon runs so you level very slow unless you are hardcore at this game.
PvP lag is very noticeable in every room.
High level nest parties are very discriminative in gear and class.
Events are pretty much cash shop related.
I r8 it 8/8

reviewText:
First off, you more likely to enjoy this game if you enjoy anime and manga (Japanese Media), since the chracters and art is stylized in that direction. I wouldn't say that all people who enjoy anime would enjoy this game, its just a common trend I've seen in players.

Things that I've been Impressed in this game:

STORY: As a F2P game, its got cut scenes and great voice acting for many of the characters. If invest the time, you can find a variety of amusing and deep storyline in the game.

USER FREINDLY: Well, its a typical Fantasy Rpg, with skills binded to action hot keys. The Games Dugeon to Dugeon action makes playing the game simple and user freindly.  Death dosn't have a major penalty and PVP play is available in specificl chanaels.

RE-PLAYABILITY: This game encourages replay ability, if gives you XP buffs to your characters though the Unified Skill system, you have Server (cross character) storage as well as a mailing system to send stuff back and forth between characters. And since theres multiple characters with multiple prestige classes, theres plenty of variety in game play styles.

If you haven't played a Nexon Game yet, you shoudl definitely give this game of Vindictus a try. It's very user freindly and have very satisfying gameplay

reviewText: Dragon Nest is like your classic RPG. You do quests and level up, yada yada ya. However, unlike games such as Mabinogi or WoW, the combat system embraces fluidity of skills. It's not turn-based and moves can be used whenever they're available during dungeons. The skill point system can be tailored to one's playstyle. It's quite enjoyable to play with friends, but playing in public parties is tolerable. The currency is easily gained and lost through progression and you don't need to spend money to access moves or slots for moves *cough* Spiral Knights *cough*. The NX cash shop, or the Dragon Vault, presents a variety of items such as costumes, which you don't really need to succeed, or functional consumables which the game gives you for free. The game's content is ever-expanding in the storyline and a lot of effort is put into it (even if most of you probably click as fast as you can through quests without reading).\n\nThere aren't a multitude of downsides that can't be solved by the player themselves, but first and foremost: Dragon Nest is licensed (?) through Nexon. Their customer support is horrid. The couple of weeks before December had a lot of problems with connection, disconnection, and overall lag. However, the compensation for issues is usually worth it. Another problem is that single-player play can get monotonous because like many RPGs, the game is grindy, but that can either be remedied by playing in a party or y'know, taking a break. The community is riddled with individuals of almost all ages, ranging from the stereotypical whiny, slightly-illiterate twelve-year old"
date: to people who are married and have kids. One last drawback is that to run certain dungeons (nests)
recommended: public parties usually require players to already be geared upon joining
hoursPlayed: however many guilds and other players are nice enough to help individuals who are new to levels and the game overall.\n\nedit: elaborated monotony"
voteText: January 4, 2014
helpfulPercent: true

reviewText:
+ Wonderful combat
+ Classic visuals art style
+ Satisfying levels and loot
+ Lots of content and quests
+ Direction; knowing where to go isn't hard to figure out
+ Story; not cheesy and far fetched
+ Inventory management is simple
+ No pay to win; you can pay for some cosmetic stuff and other things that you might like, but are not essential in any way
+ Intuitive dungeons; game is based in fields" but the combat keeps it from becoming mundane in any way
- Character creation/class selection; more classes and character customization are coming in large update though
- Classes are gender locked. e.g.) In order to be an Archer you MUST be female
date:
in order to be a Warrior you must be male

* I have not gotten to subclasses/specializations yet; I cannot review it.
* I have not tried the PvP yet; I am uninterested in PvP currently; I cannot review it.
* I have not crafted enough to have an opinion of it; I cannot review it.
* Personally
recommended: I dislike the way you learn/upgrade skills; you must pay (ingame currency) to upgrade them
hoursPlayed: so the more you upgrade the more it will cost you. Although

reviewText:
I don't like MMO's, and I don't like F2P.

I like this game anyway. For some reason it doesn't manage pull the same ♥♥♥♥♥ that pisses me off in games such as WOW or EVE, while maintaining the same basic ideas. It has the fetchquests, it has the GRIND, it has the cash store for useless items...

But its fun, which both WOW and EVE fail at on a horrific level. If you've never played an MMO, this is a good place to start. It even manages to scale nicely with dual AMD cards, which is something quite a few newer games fail to manage.

reviewText:
I'm astounded by all the positive reviews.  This game is not only a themepark, but I've never seen smaller themepark levels in my life.  I mean, it's like you go into a large closet, when you kill the mosters in there, all 8 of them, you move to a new closet kill another few monsters, and then another.  What?  That's a game?

There's no open world by any stretch of the imagination.  This isn't even remotely an MMO.  If you could compeltely revamp the game so you could actually explore a world without hitting a zone exit every 3 seconds (and I mean, 3 seconds), you might have had a decent game here.

I have no idea how people can play games like this, especially if your first games MMO's were UO, AC, EQ, and so on.  Bleah.  I played it for less than an hour and uninstalled it.  So much for the positive reviews.  It's TERRIBLE and pointless.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Game is actually pretty good for being free to play.  But if you're like most people with a job, you'll end up spending hundreds of dollars, if not thousands of dollars, into this game.  Note that money spent mostly cosmetic.  I used to have one of each class maxed and fully geared.  I was also #1 and #3 in PvP ranking in the server I was in, and was a leader of moderately successful PvE guild.  I played this game for over a year and it was fun at the time, and the raids are done well.  But the main thing about this game is that it lacks content.  Whatever they do have is pretty good, but the fact that you're forced to grind same thing over and over and over and over, just isn't very entertaining.  I may have recommended this game in the beginning, but soon you will see why I can't recommend this game.\n

reviewText:
Ok, I'm going to have to preface my review of this game with saying that I do not have at the time of this review, a character at the level 70 level cap. I plan to do so though.

As with all of my other reviews, they will be scaled from 0 to 10 on a few criteria.

Gameplay: 7.5/10: This game would get a perfect 10, if a few things were reduced/removed. A. GRINDING, Be prepared to grind your ♥♥♥ off in this game. When the game's level cap was 50, it took me several MONTHS to hit 50 on my non-boosted toon. B. Gear Upgrading, Ok, so in this game like classic Nexon fasion there is a gear upgrading ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t system. You have to spend real money to get anywhere near past about +10 on your gear, though some people are generous enough to post the jellies on the Auction House, for ♥♥♥♥TONS of Gold... These are the only things really hampering the gameplay. Otherwise, it's very fun, action based MMORPG with alot of flashy skills.

Graphics: 9/10: This game would again get a perfect 10, if 1 thing was tweaked. visual effects of the Tinkerer class. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSSuRETYUU8 watch that video if you want an explination (a very funny one)

Audio: Japan/Korean Voices: 10/10: American Voices: 8/10:  There used to be a mod for the game that added in the Korean voice actors for all of the classes, but it didnt continue after about Kali got released, If I could read Korean, I would be playing KDN because the voices are like 3000x better in that game. The american ones are just a bit too cheezy at some times, though some lines are funny. also, Shield Charge in KDN is one of my favorite lines along with the American version of Justice Crash.

Overall: 8.5 out of 10. I'm actually going to agree with IGN on this one, it's a good place to dip your toes into the F2P genera of games, and a good place to stick. PvP is fun, PvE isnt that bad, just alot of grinding. If there was a Maybe button for the Do you recommend this game, I would probably hit that one, but Yes will be good enough.

reviewText:
Although this game can have some problems. Mainly with Hack-Shield. Once you get it working, have fun with your addiction. This game is pure fun. I can't get enough.

The developers goal was to basically combine console level Hack'n'Slash gameplay with traditional MMORPG features. And it worked. It worked so well. The character customization is a bit lacking, but it is still there. The game is not a money sucker by any means. When they same Free-to-play, they mean free to play.

The graphics overall are not the greatest, even on max settings. But as long as you are not a graphics Wh*** you should be fine. But overall, the graphic style is very nice. It's bright-ish Anime inspired graphics are not exactly new to the MMO genre, but overall are nice.

I haven't even gotten to the Combat. Oh my, I can not get enough of this gameplay. The combat is absolutely gorgeous. It has your basic left-click attack. Your right click is your special. And then you have your skills, the skills are respectivly on the number keys, which does take a little while to get use to at first. But after awhile it won't be so irritating.

The music in this game is also quite beautiful, and works perfectly in the background to build tension. It is no Kingdom Hearts or Elder Scrolls, but it is still quite nice. The composers did a nice job.

Gameplay 9.7
Sound 8.8
Graphics 7.6
Replay value 10

Overall 8.9/10

~RadiantNight7

reviewText:
I haven't been playing long so if you need to decide if you are going to get this game, look to a review from someone who has spent at least 30 hrs in game.
I am here to share my first impressions. I'll start with the bad: the game is very cookie cutter, story line, level grind, being usless untill level 20, and so on. I have also seen better graphics, WAY BETTER. The game also feels frustratingly easy, but takes a long  time. It's like every other F2P MMO out there.
BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE!
Now for the good stuff; the game is adorable, the npc's have funny personalities, It's quick to understand, and really fun, almost relaxing. But what is really unique about this game is the community. I was playing for the first time trying to figure out what to do and bam, in the first FIVE minutes I met three people (all higher level than me) just hanging around, who invited me to their party. Two minutes later they where going on all my quests with me and showing me what to do. They helped me until I reached lvl 10 when I had to get off and catch some sleep. We have keept in touch since then but it's really cool how I met them so soon and how friendly they where, I'm used to playing games where nearly everyone is lone wolf" kinda thing but It's really nice to have people to party up with and just hang out.

I'm keeping this short and sweet so overall first impression is: I'm No longer forever alone. This game is fun

reviewText: Action MMO that does so much perfectly. Where I live (US) the game feels fluid, no lag, no delay on when I press a move do I see my character reacting. This feeling is so importnant and most games fail to deliver on this. The game is a little micro transaction heavy. Simple things that should be free or earned (like inv space, respecs) are pay for. Also costume items have stats so while they aren't make or break good, they do give a serious boost when added up. One other thing that could be considered bad is some of the best stuff (like big wings that make you run faster) can only be obtained via Dragon Eggs" which are pay for booster packs that contain a random item. This makes it very cool when you get something but also makes you hesitate to buy an egg
date: becuase it could be a whammy. Overall the gameplay is awesome
recommended: story is very random and anime-like. Lots of fun even if you stay away from the pay shop."

reviewText: This is one, if not, the best of all of the MMORPGS I have every played, and have had the pleasure to experience.  The storyline is amazing, and keeps you wanting to read most of the dialogue the characters have to offer, the many landscapes look beautiful, even with the old-school type graphics this game harbours. And, finally, the gameplay. It is the best aspect of this game so far, and it's what makes this game different from other MMORPGS. You feel like you're actually controlling your character; it isn't the same 'point and click' formula which has, unfortunately, taken control of most other MMORPGs of the era. Above all else, this game manages to be a unique, excellent experience which I am sure that you will all treasure.

reviewText:
First off- the most important thing is: the most fun I have had in a game since I was about ~12 (I'm 27, and i'm talking about FF7). The action in this game is... amazing. Fast paced, intense, and above all it's just fun.

Also, character progression is great. Each class specs into 2 different tiers, and from there 2 more, etc. This, combined with the fact that you can spend your points on different abilities, means you can have 2 people from the class performing different roles and adds uniqueness (kinda) and flexibility. Each new ability you unlock can be dramatic, and the best part is you can pump points into any of them depending on how you want to play your character. I hate when games have the useful skills and the useless ones, and it's just a no brainer.

Unfortuantely (and this may have changed since i last played- let me know if it has) the in-game economy is set to nickel and dime you to death. I played up to level cap (when it was 50). Each new level they give you items to seal your good equip/items (thus allowing you to sell on the player2player market, otherwise your item is tied to your character). But as soon as you reach level cap, you get no more of these. This means, once you are out, as i was, you have to pay a ridiculous price for these seals. I can't remember what the price was, but it was ludicrous. There are free ones you collect in the game, but after playing for hours upon hours (i think my game time was arounf 172 hours?) i blew all of them and got maybe a few to work, if that. The rate of success on these free ones was so low, and the price of the paid ones so high, that it wasn't worth playing anymore because I essentially couldn't make a decent amount of money and i certainly didn't want to ditch my epic gear to an in game store for pennies. I sincerely hope that has changed since i stopped, but i doubt it has. Let me know though if it has, because i would LOVE to pick this game up again.

Also, i only dabbled in the PVP, but it was very good from what i played.

If this game had an option to buy it outright for a set price ($60? i would pay more even...) and just let you buy and sell freely in the market, maybe with some other options, it would be in my top 10 games ever, imho.

All in all, i would highly recommend playing this game- only with the foresight of knowing not to let yourself get addicted, only to have withdrawals when you force yourself off of it at level cap (when things get really interesting). Or maybe even play to level cap, and then start a new character.

reviewText: Amazing action MMO that delivers quite a bit of content. Starter classes branch into more elaborate and specialized paths that only enhance the enjoyment of the game. Although the game is based around instances/dungeons, the action and varied monsters make up for the lack of an open world. Can't seem to find any other game that deliver the same action as this game. The cutesy anime graphics may put off some potential players, but for those who do not mind the anime-like graphics will find this game enjoyable. Dungeons/instances are always more fun with friends, but solo play is still pretty fun to play through. A very recommended game for those who seek a true action MMO. ^_^

reviewText:
Game's fun. Hop on it.

Edit: Okay, finally, time for an actual (really quick) review.

Dragon Nest is an Action-MMO (Aka, not your typical tab-target, spam F1-F5 MAX DPS ROTATION GOOOO WoW clone) with a fairly deep story, and decently done in game cinematics.

Its a dungeon based 3d-beat-em-up meets MMO essentially. There are 6 characters, each with 2 subclasses, and then 2 more subclasses branching from those, and a 7th character (The Assassin) somewhere down the line coming.

Controls are pretty tight, and the game looks great. Each class has a large amount of varied skills, and you have the freedom to build the characters how you want (though, there are obviously prereqs for skills you may have to meet).

NPCs are actually fun to talk to, and there's quite a large amount of dungeons in game.

Those things being said, there are a few downsides, and I highly suggest you take them into consideration before you sink time (and money) into the game:

1. While leveling, you'll find yourself making very long trips into town to talk to a bunch of really spread out npcs for questing reasons. Its tolerable in Lotus Marsh and the starter towns since they're pretty small, but its utterly atrocious in Saint's Haven, as its such a big place, and entering the castle counts as a map change. It drags the pace of the game down considerably at times.

2. Its hosted by Nexon. For those of us familiar with them, I need not say more. For those who aren't, Nexon is a VERY greedy company, known for charging their players out the (insert word for butt here) for many things. While the game is free to play, you'll find yourself wanting avatars (armor that provides slight stat bonuses, but mainly exists for cosmetic reasons), and other things from their in-game shop. The prices in the shop for said avatars are misleading, as those are the prices for the shortest duration non-permanent version of the item. Instead, if you wish to keep things forever, you'll find yourself paying about 5 bucks per piece, which well, is a lot. Which is further compounded by the fact that NX items are not tradeable, so you can't just buy them off other people with in-game money outside of specific circumstances.

Those two probems aside (pace-breaking quest gathering sequences that take up to 20 minutes sometimes), and overpriced cash shop items, its an extremely fun game gameplay-wise, and I'd suggest checking it out if you're looking for an actual game when you think of MMOs.

reviewText: A very diverse game with a very smooth feel. The controls make you feel like you are in control of it all. The graphics aren't the greatest in the world, but the motion capture is very smooth to make up for that. The storylines are very unique and complete. The way you level is easier than most games. The end of the class trees are at level 45, unlike the level 70 that most other games have. You don't get bored while playing this game. You have to be alert to what is happening and be a step ahead of everyone else.

reviewText: The odd art style is easily forgiveable for its intense combat and excellent presentation (with humorous, well translated dialogue for those interested in that). The presence of a pay-to-win shop is not as prominent as other games (if vanity items like instant use potions could be considered pay-to-win), since personal skill is as important a factor in survival as your gears. Hack-and-slash veterans will feel comfortable fighting at difficulties higher than what the design recommends. Although the sound design might not be as sharp as AAA titles, it gets the job done and isn't a massive distraction, with character voicing appropriate for their personalities.\n\nIt's definitely worth trying.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game but DO NOT download the STEAM VERSION. Go to Nexon's official website at http://dragonnest.nexon.net/ and download their client instead. The steam version is regularly plagued by log-in and patching issues and the only fix is to re-download the game every single time. Nexon and Steam doesn't seem to care about this version anymore.

Now, on to the review! If you want action-oriented MMORPG with flashy / cool-looking moves then Dragon Nest is the game for you. You have your basic rpg classes in the form of Warrior, Archer, Cleric and Sorcerer. The other available classes are Tinkerer (a sort of engineer) and Dancer. Upcoming classes are Assassin and Lancer.

The world is instance type wherein areas (including towns) are separated like dungeons. Although, the towns are very big themselves. The dungeons get bigger and bigger as you progress into the game. Lastly, the environment details are well made and numerous.

You gain exp in the game by killing mobs in dungeons, clearing the dungeons themselves and completing NPC quests. When you gain a level you get skill points which you can use to unlock your skills. Core stats are pre-set by the game. Pretty much a standard level and skill system. There's a nifty feature wherein you can see a demo of a skill first before you get it. That way, you can see if you'll like the skill or not.

Exp is very fast from Level 1 to 50. 50 to 70 is when the grind starts but still doable and not boring because of the awesome combat system. If you're a hardcore player that can sit a whole day in front of a computer then you can get to the level cap in a week or so. If you're a casual player like me, at level 50 onwards you can gain 2 levels a day or 4 while still being able to stand up and do other stuff. That's pretty fast by today's MMORPG standards.

I won't go into the other details of the game because to be honest, it's very big even though it's instanced type. I just provided feedback on the basic features that players tend to look forward to.

So again, if you're into action and flashy moves, this is the game for you. You're not really missing anything by not dowloading the Steam version so go the Nexon website I provided on this review and get their client instead. Trust me, it'll be less hassle in the long run.

Nexon Dragon Nest Official Website:
http://dragonnest.nexon.net/

reviewText: I'm going to say it right now: this game is  VERY  grindy." If you plan on getting the  decent  gear or that top pvp ladder spot you better be ready to grind those dungeons till your eyes bleed. It is very much a grind-to-win game. And is the very standard "Collect X amounts of stuff" MMO crap that we have come to enjoy (sarcasm). The story is mediocre at best. Customer support is quite possible one of the worst
date: as the publisher is Nexon.\n\nThat being said though
recommended: it still has it's great moments. If you just sit back and ignore all of those fancy collectables and pvp lags
hoursPlayed: you will realize that it can be enjoyable. The skills and classes are very diverse and offer a lot of interesting combos and techniques to play around with in both pvp and pve. The community (for the most part) is friendly and willing to help you if need be. And the variety of enemies the game throws at you keeps pve challenging and engaging.\n\n5.5/10 This game barely edges out on my scale. Do not play this game unless you like running the same dungeon repeatedly because you will not like it. However
voteText: if you are truly just in it for the experience and not the competitiveness
helpfulPercent: it can still be an entertaining game."

reviewText: Another online game by Nexon that is similar to Vindictus, but definately different.  Dragon Nest has a bit more of an RPG feel to it than Vindictus. The control is a bit different and resembles more like a mix of Vindictus and Guild Wars 2. However like other free online RPGs, its not really MMO, and its not very open world.  Missions are fun, but NPCs make you do them over and over. 4 character classes to choose from (again gender locked), Fighter(Male), Cleric,(Male) Archer(Elf fFemale), and sorceress (Female).  At upper levels you get class changes and take different class specializations.  Lots of fun, but you will tire of it if you play too much.

reviewText: This is a fun game, its made by the same company who published Vindictus, the graphics are great, the battle system is good, each class has one thing or person they have to protect or save.  But you can choose from 4 classes, each with their own unique abilities and strengths. So if you want a fun MMORPG, you should download this game and try it. Character design is pretty cool, the enemies can be a tad bit difficult, but hey what do you expect? for the enemies to stay at an easy level? lol, whats the fun in that , seriously.... But all in all you shoudl try this game, if you like MMORPG's. The only thing i dont like about this, well is that its llike Vindictus, meaning that you cant really free roam in this game, but oh well. Its a very good game if you like the MMORPG style like Vindictus, its very fun, and you can lose countless hours in it and not even realising it

reviewText: Fun and intense, true free fighting Dragon Nest is one of my favorite MMO's that are free to play. Its diverse fighting is one of the best little features in the game. Anime style graphics make this game look great. When your fighting you will definatley feel like you are breaking the earth. Only setbacks of this game is it is gender locked and that there isnt very much character customization. Sooner or later though NA (North America) will get more classes such as the Assassin which is Dragon Nests' biggest project at the minute. The Assassin is only available in its birth place, Korea, and is based on what his name is, an assassin. Very good game, despite those bad features the game looks great and is very fun and addicting.

reviewText: First off, I'd like to say that I'm not a huge fan of MMO's, but I do attempt some to see how I like them. And this one I absolutely fell in love with. It's got great gameplay (feels more like 3rd person action than an MMO, which I like) with some awesome abilities you can gain, a pretty good story that actually goes in depth, compared to some other MMO's I've played, and actually has some characters that you grow to care for. Not to mention that the style is very nice, along with the designs of most of the weapons and armor.\n\nThe ONLY issue I would have to say (but this could be said about other games as well), is that when you get to higher levels, like 45+, you will need to grind so much XP, it can be a bit teadious. But, if you have a group of friends, or can make some new ones on here, then you can go do some nice raids, and high level grinding, and that'll help out a bit. Otherwise, this game is pretty awesome, and I've enjoy every moment I've spent playing it.

reviewText: The best of both worlds! Action and RPG elements. This isn't your traditional MMORPG! Great anime style graphics, overly steroided monsters and tons of bouncy goodness. One of the few free to play games where you don't get stuck until you spend money in the online store. Without spending a penny you have access to the full game. This game is highly recommended for people who have become jaded with the standard World of Warcraft clones out there. You can actually make real progress playing an hour at a time instead of having to organize a raid that takes 8-10 hours of nonstop game play. Even the largest dungeon takes an hour or less.

reviewText: A fun action MMO with a colorful look, a sense of humor, and a lot to keep you coming back for more.  It's geniunely plain entertaining, and pretty easy to get into, letting you enjoy the game without trying to sort out too much arcana or data dumps.  Game progression is also logical, so there's always something new to try out.  Stylistically the cartoony nature keeps it light, though there are elements of odd fanservice, seriousness, and irreverance that don't quite gel and seem odd.  However that's no reason not play what is honestly a good, fun, and rather precise game, wether you want to melt foes with fire, smash them with a sword, or just release a mechanical butler and a legion of roboducks.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest

Immediately the art style drew me to this game, so I tried it out. Dragon Nest has a wide variety of classes, each with stats that resemble that class which makes realistic gameplay. It also has a great levelling system, quest system, inventory and arena systems, alongside guilds, as well as parties with fair loot drops for its members. The varied weapons, gear and other items always gives you incentive to keep playing. With its fast action 3rd person gameplay, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes fast paced MMORPG's. This game breaks away from the top down MMO’s and does it well. Overall an amazing game for the solo player or the team player.

reviewText:
Won best PvP of E3 2011. That's when it was still growing here. This game due to verious reasons , one being it's art style , is what makes this game subjective to your taste. Some people played for a bit and wrote it off as unbalanced or child-like. Clearly not giving it much of a chance.

First off it is in no way a pay-to-win.
Second I've never seen too many games where your level is NOT the main thing that matters , but skill. An example when i first started I had a guild carry me to level 24 . I then faced a level 10 in pvp and lost. He knew what he was doing unlike me.

With such a large variety or armour , sub-classes , and side-quest. It allows you to create and mold a unique powerful character to your liking. The story various character to character giving you more in-depth gameplay.

Movement is fluid , fighting smooth. The game and the players never ceases to challenge you . You wont get bored unless you spoil it for your self. I mean that in a lot of ways. The fun in this game comes with the story, not knowing what new move you'll get next level, discovering new places, ccreating amazing weapons and armour, defining your character, and playing with the community. Ignore these things and trying to hard can ruin the experience of any mmo for you. Dont outcast yourself and just try and enjoy it.

The only con i can actually think of is , gender lock. A lot of people just left huh? Well if gender choice is a must have , still give it a shot. If you are not having fun by level 25 (if you followed the quest the right way and paced your self) then go ahead and drop it. However you will be missing out.

Lastly have fun. Some characters might not be for you, try something else. Try talking to people. Figure out how to fight. What moves work. Learn how to do and use things from certain quest. This game keeps you on your toes. Everything seems over whelming at first , but it is much simpler then you realize, and a lot more fun too.

Personal opinon. Your first class just go for it. learn from your mistakes. you can always make a second class and trust me , eatch class is different enough where it wont be tedious in anway to start over. reviewText: This game is a fun and challenging action MMO set up with a fast-paced dungeon crawling experiance and a great social community. The camera is third person so you always feel like your in the action, with movement being in the WASD, The free to play system is fair and does NOT really affect balance between players, i.e. pay to win situation. Most of your money goes into cosmetics anywa. Plus the game runs, and looks great! I do recommend that you play with friends and take on harder, but more rewarding challenges. A lot of fun is to be had with friends. The only thing that may be discouraging is that you can't choose the specific sex you want to play as for each class. So if you want to be a female, warrior-brute, sorry :/  I didn't have any big gripes with that though. I would say go in, pick your play style, and have fun!

reviewText:
Action packed RPG with tonnes of nuianced, creative, and just plain fun game play.  Beautiful in game art and cutscenes.  Some of the best writing, storylines, and NPC character development I have seen in forever. Immense in scope and pursuable quests. Clever crafting, character building, market system, and social interaction. Dragon Nest is an easter egg on Steam that it seems few people know about and part of me doesnt want to share, but the people who make this game possible should have their coffers lined with gold for such a well made excellently written and enjoyable game.

Suggestion:
1. Don't be afraid of challenging and even angering some players with impossible to beat quests.Abyss difficulty at any character level of play should be nigh impossible without a team no matter how good you, equipment, and teammates are.
Inscrutable difficulty wins respect, is the best pr, and get the most diehard loyal fans which this truly great game deserves in spades.

Likers Like. Haters gonna hate. Gamers, play this game and you will have fun.

reviewText:
To preface about myself, I've been playing this game since beta, and have well over 500 hours logged on this, since the switch to using Steam for Dragon Nest was relatively recent.

I have a great time playing this game. It recently got revamped to make leveling from 1-50 easier, although it will still take time. It's definitely possible to finish the story line with just the gear you get from quests, although getting really good gear will definitely take time and in-game currency. While there are people who trade NX for gold and vice versa, this game is most definitely not pay 2 win, but there are many costumes and cosmetic customizations that you can purchase within the NX store. While those cosmetic items do indeed have stats, they're definitely not needed to be well-geared for raids.

Class elitism doesn't exist for the most common things, such as nests, although once you start getting into raids and other really tough things to clear, people will definitely have class preferences. That said, it's good to visit the forums on dragonnest.nexon.net and read about different classes, as well as do some googling on what's easiest to gear, what class is cheapest to get good at, etc, before jumping into this game.

Most people I've met were extremely friendly, and it's never hard to party up and work with people for nests and quests. Guilds are also awesome in this game. There are many, and different types exist for different players, so everyone from casual to hardcore can find guilds to suit them. The market is also really well done now, and buying/selling is a smooth process.

The fighting system is real-time and 3D, which makes for an AWESOME gameplay. It's super fast and has pve and pvp within the game, with reward systems and ability to acquire weapons by doing either. It's not all about stats - your ability to dodge monsters' abilities, other people's abilities, and the whole cartoon animation style is great.

The one con that I would mention is that once you get really high level and your power runs out quickly, the game can get somewhat boring unless you have a guild or a group of friends to do raids and nests with. Being purely a solo player is a lonesome and boring life once you hit 70, and grinding does exist for the last 10-15 levels until you hit the cap.

Overall I'd rate this game 8.5/10. It's solid,
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, I decided to get back into Dragon Nest after a long break. I joined when the cap was around lvl 40, and it's lvl 80 now so lets get to it.
Pros
-You can solo most content
-Applying for guilds is really easy
-Joining parties is easy
-Cash Shop isn't super OP
-You have a chance each week to earn FREE cash shop items from a dungeon called Treasure Dungeon
-Raids/Nests are extremely fun
-Lots of helpful peeps, some trolls doe
Cons
-Can take kind of long to level if you're not in a guild
-Class discrimintation
-PVP has a learning curve/ Kind of unbalanced
-Most people hate this, gender locked classes. Doesn't really bother me, but to some it's a real turn off

Overall a great game to enjoy with friends. If you don't have friends playing just join a guild and strike up conversations with guildies. (How I did it, forever alone T_T)

reviewText: Honestly this is a fun game. Being a free to play, it has some pay elements like costumes, wings that boost movement speed, and harder to get costumes to get even more bonuses, HOWEVER you can buy all of this off of other, TRUSTED gamers with in game gold. It is incredibly easy to make gold in this game if you just try a bit. Combat is incredibly fun and relatively simple to get the hang of, but if you want to do any 4 man nests or 8 man raids right when they come out, i recomemd voice chat for organization and learning purposes. Trust me, makes life easy. The community is admitedly a little terrible due to some imbalances in the classes, but the developer, Eye, is working on these imbalances. I think in a year or 2 it will be evened out into dps-tier based classes. Classes with the least support having massive dps, classe with more support having lower overall dps,  but a massive Burst damage attack they can rely on to keep themselves keeping on. However, you can still find people who want to play against the meta, because honestly... Meta parties take almost no skill to run, and are all about deleting bosses. There are many good groups of players who wont descriminate, you just have to find them. Final note is RNG. It is EVIL. you could be well invested and all set to enhance your shiney new Unique item to +10, and burn through about 80$ worth of enhancement materials (buyable from other players mind you, about 8-10k gold worth) plus a couple thousand gold and end up with a +8 from degrades. However... you could also get to +12 without a single failure. RNG. its random. Luckily, this system will be improved at the current level cap, level 80 epic grade and above equipement will not downgrade until +8, and only one level if they do. Other issues with RNG are when you carry a scrub in a dungeon, they roll on the rare drop, win it, and run off. But hey, it is an mmorpg, thats expected. At least KSing isnt a thing. anyway, decide for yourselves. All games have flaws, but there is alot of fun in this game despite its flaws. find a good group to hang with, get gear, have fun. Good Luck

reviewText:
This is unlike any other MMO that is currently on the market. It features crazy fast, arcade-like action mixed with the strategy and planning of an MMO. It has a very engaging story that makes your decisions in quests feel like they matter with great humor scattered throughout the whole thing.

In addition to this, all of the content is free. You don't have to buy your levels or your raids, you only buy cosmetic items. And while those cosmetics offer special bonuses for characters which are helpful, they don't impact the game in such a way that it turns it into pay to win".

Would play with friends.
Would play solo.
Would recomend for anyone."

reviewText: While you oft run into long periods of grinding (Especially 60+), and the updates are few and far between, I find this game fairly fun. The most glaring of which is the lack of anything to do at the level cap (which has steadily risen since I started playing this game). At level 60+, your options are essentially limited to grinding and Nests. And did I mention that the level 60 nests are impossible to do alone?\n\nNote: This review is based on possibly old experience, although I doubt it, given how little this game is updated.

reviewText:
Before I get into this review, it's worth noting that there isn't much of a midway standpoint when it comes to Dragon Nest.  In other words, you either like it or you don't. That's not to say you shouldn't give it enough time to judge whether you want to keep playing or not, but really, for the most part, you either like it... or you don't.

Now for starters, Dragon Nest is a free-to-play RPG. And this time, when I say free-to-play, I do mean it. One great thing about DN (Dragon Nest) is that you really can go through the entire game/an entire character and not spend a single penny. If you like the game however (and there's a good chance you do if you make it past level 30), you're likely going to end up spending a fair amount of money to make your character look fabulous. Besides the money aspect, DN is also an action MMO alongside it's RPG genre, and it has 'action oriented combat', meaning it's unlike the boring* point-and-click attack scheme most other MMOs have going for them. It's fast paced, and when you get used to it, you'll find yourself pulling off ridiculous arrays of relentless combos without even thinking about it.

Dragon Nest currently has nine classes (one of which is currently limited to a 1-month creation period), each of which branch into two unique sub-classes, of which branch into two final sub-classes as well, excluding the Lancea class (which only has one first spec) and the new 'Dark' Class, which is a linear path. For the most part, each class handles very differently from one another, (the exception being not the playstyle itself but rather the roles each class takes on e.g. dps, tank, or healer), and each class also has a unique set of skills that the player can string together to form combos.

Now to get into the meat of the game: the combat. The combat in DN is exceptional for most MMOs out there... in a specific way. Now what I mean by that can be taken a few different ways, so allow me to explain. Whereas Warframe's combat is rewarding in it's smoothness and executability, Dragon Nest's combat is rewarding due to it's magnitude. This still sounds strange, but think of it this way: there is no class that is not a hard-hitting class. In Dragon Nest, every class has at least several obsurdly powerful abilities. Powerful in size, not damage. In PvE, you find yourself facing waves of enemies rather than groups of two or three, and this is countered by the insane AoE abilities Dragon Nest has to offer. Rather than swinging your sword back and forth a few times to hit an enemy in front of you, you swing it once, and it sends a shockwave of dust at your enemies causing them to fly backwards and die. In DN, it's quantity combat. That's the best way to put it.

Finally, I'll mention PvP - since it's a large aspect of the game for many players - even though my knowledge on it is limited. The PvP in Dragon Nest is incredibly fast-paced. Seriously. If you're against a skilled Windwalker, good luck and good bye. Now that's not to say DN's PvP is unfair, because it most certainly is not. The PvP system uses percentiles, so even when facing higher-level opponents (aside from the amount of abilities unlocked) it remains fair and balanced. Again, my knowledge on this particular aspect of the game remains limited, since I avoid PvP, but if you want a hint (pick Assassin for PvP it's nuts).

Overall, I'd just say give DN a shot. I loaded up the game several months ago half-expecting an unfinished pile of laughable potatos, but what I got was less laughs and more gasps as I slowly discovered the charm that is Dragon Nest. To reiderate, just give it a try. You'll know if you like it or if you don't. And on the offchance you do, I'll see you there.


*PERSONAL OPINION








(And I swear if the second spec for Lancea isn't a Scythe wielding class I'm going to replace my hardrive with a potato)

I am now running my PC off approximately 3.5 volts of potato juice

reviewText: I love this game. Honestly, when I first saw it, I thought it was going to be like all of the other MMORPGs. Basic few classes, leveling, lack of people, and then get bored maybe a week or two into it, but I have been playing for over a year now, and I think it's awesome. There are not only 7 different classes with another on the way to choose from, but each class gets a subclass at level 15, and then it splits yet again into more customization at level 45. There is no lack of players, either. There are multiple channels filled with players in all of the different cities. Party play is fun and the dungeons are expansive. I absolutely recommend this game to the MMO players out there. If you've ever played Vindictus, it has a similiar game-play, but a bit more anime-esque. Try it!

reviewText:
Heavily stylized, varried gameplay, visually interesting enemies, action-rpg elements, and a system that allows for the building of 'relationships' with NPC's and their factions through an NPC gifting system*, knowledgable and friendly community - What more could you want from an Action-RPG MMO? If you want more 'realism' in your art style check Vindictus - themeatically similar elements and familiar Action-RPG gameplay.

Accessable, Free to Play, less of a grind and more of a light hearted good time.
If the art style is the only thing stoping you from checking it out - to each their own. Check out Vindictus instead, another F2P light hearted title from the same publisher.

*The NPC/Faction/Renown gifting system is incredibly grindy, the gifts are relatively common drops but you need hundreds upon hundreds to make an impact.

reviewText:
I've returned to my old account after a year and was playing on the Nexon Launcher which will explain the lack of hours recorded on steam. This review is meant to be a general overview on the gameplay, graphics and what to expect for returning players or new players completely new to this game going from level 1 to 90.

Good The combat is fast paced and can be quite fun with the various combos you can use
Sub-class system is something that you can look forward to when progressing through the game
The storyline content is actually quite good in my opinion (Assassin storyline)
Everything except for the newest content and raids are soloable
Bad The textures are atrocious even on highest quality settings
Upon entering Saint's Haven everyone WILL have wings, glowing weapons and all manner of cosmetics that will make you look like you crawled out of the gutter
Everyone WILL be more geared than you
You WILL be flooded with free and/or time-limited cash shop items that you WILL have no idea what to do with them
You WILL run the same dungeon 4-6 times each during the course of the storyline
You WILL be confused with NPC's all over the map that act as exchange shops for items that you don't understand how to use (Goddess Lament - Priestess of Darkness)
There is NO collision detection on the weaker mobs
Mounts seem kinda useless relative to just teleporting to NPC's through map
They removed Hard and Abyss Mode for most of the dungeons under Level 80?
Classic Catch22, trying to get good gear to run the latest raid when NO one wants to run with you due to your crummy gear
Late game dungeons absolutely crushes your FTG
Don't forget the dragon eggs to make your bank account cry
It's a fun game to pick up if you want to try something new, but I do not recommend this game long term.

Glossary:
FTG: A gauge that decreases everytime you enter a dungeon, the exp in dungeons gets a bonus but you get a penalty if the gauge is depleted
Abyss: One of the harder difficulty levels for a dungeon, mobs are significantly tougher
Dragon Eggs: The typical gachapons in most MMORPGs
Goddess Lament: One of the many tokens" you farm for on dailies or quests in order to exchange these "tokens" at the NPC for desired items"

reviewText:
I've recently gone over my review and noticed it was... rather plain, and didn't give any indication as to the actualy quality of this game, so allow me to elaborate. Dragon Nest is a game made by Nexon and, what I would call, like Vindictus' younger brother. The combat is very involved as compared to other MMORPG's and skills are very satisfying to use. All-in-all, I would say Dragon Nest is a very fun MMORPG and if you like Vindictus, you will most likely enjoy this game.

Pros:
- Cutesy Anime Style (Maybe a con if you're not into that?)
- Runs fairly well
- Satisfying/Solid Combat
- Straight-forward and easy to understand
- Not Pay-to-win (Last I checked anyway...)
- Has the general quality one can expect from a Nexon game

Cons:
- Progress slows down rather significantly around level 40
- Difficult to gear-up later on
- PvP is incredibly broken

The bottom line is, I haven't really had any bad experiences with Dragon Nest, and it's F2P, so why not give it a try?

reviewText: Just another awful F2P Korean MMO clone of a clone of a clone.  The graphics are on par with PS2 B-grade titles, but the game still stutters like crazy due to the Tera / Zelda style realtime action combat.  The worst part of the game are the zones.  They're as big as a closet and you're required to battle about ~25 enemies at once.  There is no room to manuever or do anything other than spam buttons ala God of War.  While you hit one enemy there are three flanking you from the sides and rear.  It feels like a single player game instead of an MMO because up to level 10 I saw maybe two other players the entire night.  The quests are lame and non inspiring with awful translations of the original humor
date: just like every other crappy Korean mass produced MMO.  For a newbie to MMOs it might not be not bad, but anyone that's played an RPG or MMO that wasn't made over 10 years ago on a modern computer will just roll their eyes and uninstall after 15 minutes.

reviewText: Dragon Nest is an amazing interactive online action mmo. The combat system is along the lines of Kingdoms of Amalur (with flashier skills) with a 4 player Co-op dungeon system added into it. It also has a branching job advancement system where you choose your path of skill development depending on your preferences. The game started with 4 classes: Warrior, Mage, Archer, and Priest, Since the 2 more classes have been added: Alchemist and Dancer. The Thief/Assassin is currently in Korea and on its way to the US soon. I'm sure more classes will be available for years to come. I suggest you watch this video  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qRRj-av5lTY " to see the  way skills look in the game. Everyone has their preferences
date: but I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS TO ACTION RPG FANS LOOKING FOR SOME FUN CO-OP OR SINGLEPLAYER ACTION! IT'S FREE TOO!"

reviewText:
Dragon nest is a pretty damn solid game. Before you say I haven't played it, I've played 200+ hours from their website, not through steam.

The combat system is excellent, It's modestly free to play, (the one exception is mounts, it's like 40$ for a chance to get one, but mounts have miniscule use. Trust me.) Dragon nest is an extremely immersive game. The classes are all very fun, and pretty balanced. The only downside is, content updates are rare, being a asian game, we get patches 1/2 YEARS later.

Important things to note about dragon nest.

The entire game is balanced around PvE, this doesn't mean the PvP is utter ♥♥♥♥, but it's not as good as it could be. Most classes are way stronger in PvP then PvE (namely Kali.). The PvE is 100% instance based. Not once will you find a mob that isn't in an instance.

My honest opinion ratings:

Combat (overall): 9.5/10
PvE: 9/10
PvP: 8/10
P2W (pay to win 1 being very much so, 10 being not at all): 8/10
Graphically: 5/10 (the game really lacks in this. The ♥♥♥♥♥iest of laptops can run this game fine.)
Overall: 8/10
Bottom line is, this game should not be overlooked. Download this game, and you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Personal opnion: This game is very good but at some point repetetive. There is some hilarious parts in this and it has potential to be very good. I recommend to play this with friends or you might be bored is a couple minutes unless your used to lonly repetetiveness. after a while this game feels boring so i suggest playing this when your bored. The download time is pretty good for a game with this type of stuff in it. In all i  i belive that this game gets a 7.5/10. its fine if you dont agree with my opinion we all have are opinion.

Graphics: Graphics are just fine some times there dull and feel ok-ish but its good graphics. The graphics are fine if you dont mind them personally i dont mind them. At the same time thee graphics are AWESOME it has some detail but compared to other pc games in 2012 its about a fair-ish judgment atleast for my standards.

Gameplay: The Gameplay is fairly simple as for a mmo rpg with your types of skills and how you build your character.
Theres not to much about leveling up and skills its kinda like all rpg skill stuff. As if it comes to customisations to your character there goes the something about this game i dont like because once you have made your character the only thing that changes about it is you characters weapon and thats it no armor change when you put on different armor this dosent bug me too much. as for the fighting machanics this is very simple to acomplish as all of it is going in worlds fighting by clicking and activating your skills by pressing 1 2 3 and etc. In this game the many levels you play have difficultly and thats your choice on which you choose which is good i like a challenge some times. As for other gameplay aspects i did not cover i think the gameplay could be improved a slight bit.

Music: As for music there are some music to comfort you as you roam around fighting in each level and the city. Theres not to much to talk about music as when you play this game your more likely to ignore it as for playing while listenning but still the music was a nice feature so you dont get bored :3. I honestly found the music as for trying to listen to it its ok to take a while to stop and listen and relax....

And here is the end of the worst review in the world i bet no one will read this and etc cya.

reviewText:
Dragon Nest:

Much like the latest Folger's commercial, Dragon Nest doesn't seek to surpass the typical MMO, it looks to land right where every single other one has already innovated, and in most cases, the others have done so in much more engaging and profound ways.  In fact, Dragon Nest doesn't tread any new ground what-so-ever.

Prepare for another... Umm... Adventure?  Dragon Nest features a tired storyline that never engages the player, character classes and progressions you've seen for the last decade (or two), an uninspired crafting and upgrade system that's been done to death by every j/k-RPG on the market, and an overpriced cash shop that attempts to lure you in with functions that remove many of the, simply put, intentional annoyances of trying to play the game, such as pitifully limited inventory space and automatic loot pickups.

Gameplay is nearly completely combat-based, with drawn-out town segments featuring quest gathering and loot selling.  Combat fails to innovate; expect keyboard gymnastics and mouse-flinging typical of this genre, often interrupted by loading screens every few minutes.  Seriously... The loading screens destroy any immersion to be had here.

I would dare to say that the game features some unique artwork and a handful of beautifully modelled monsters and characters, but most of the game centers around scantily-clad female characters (because that's what appeals to the typical gamer, right guys?) which you are introduced to immediately during the game's first loading screen, and 'emo' androgenous males that have left their provocative" stink on every RPG from the east since Square-Enix.

Music and sound effects are nothing worth mentioning; I was mostly annoyed by the droning music clips that are featured and muted it within an hour of my playtime.  Sound effects are cartoonish and repetitive
date: and their lack of variety becomes painfully apparent during combat.  It should be no surprise that the voice acting featured in the game is top-notch
hoursPlayed: steaming garbage-on-a-hot-summer-day that always sounds completely out of context; how these voice actors are cast or maintain careers is completely lost on me.\n\nThe story begins with you being some ho-hum walking randomly through the wilderness
voteText: and two little girls are attacked by orcs
helpfulPercent: one being some oracle that you're desperately trying to save for eons
votesHelpful: yet every single time you get close
votesTotal: you feel like you should see "Sorry Mario
votesFunny: but the princess is being held in another castle!"  Oh
commentsCount: and there are evil dragons
column16: apparently.  Most NPC dialogue seems to assume you know what's going on in this world
column17: but the game doesn't ever make an earnest attempt at introducing any of the lore to you so that you know what the hell is going on.\n\nOverall
column18: Dragon Nest is a mediocre game; it doesn't innovate in any area
column19: and it's formula is tried and true.  It may be free-to-play
column20: but it makes every possible attempt to make you open your wallet to essentially unbreak itself.  Being a Nexon game
column21: expect their lovely gem 'HackShield' to break and crash your game on a near-hourly basis
column22: often throwing false-positives or simply having some kind of failure that will cause you to lose your progress mid-dungeon.\n\n3 / 10"

reviewText:
It's an action rpg game with short instances that you can play with friends.

Pros:
- Different classes to choose from with each two different specializations
- Gear and loot
- Action combo based gameplay
- Graphics are correct

Cons:
- Buggy collision (sometimes you hit right on enemy and there is no effect
- Gameplay feels mechanic even though it is more actif than your average rpg game.
- Lots of quest about talking to a serie of npcs early in game without any explanation about how the game works, juste about some basic background story for some npcs. (could be a positive aspect for some people, I personally just wanted to play and try the gameplay before getting into the side story)
- Not a lot of explanation about how to regroup or join friends that aren't at the same starting point as you. (Comes when you can meet, but you have to play 3-4 instances before you can really join.

Simply not a game for me. It was over hyped by the community and compared to Vindictus in term of action. I can affirm there is no ressemblance. It is was more mechanical than its Nexon's related.

reviewText: Dragon nest is the **** it's like playing a single player role playing game with friends.The dungeons are insane and the gameplay  is epic. All the skills are different for each class. Six different classes each with there own subclass The animation may look child like but don't get it wrong the game will blow your mind. Also you don't even need to read the npc text just watching the cutscenes will give you the facts about what going on in the story. There tons of dungeons and pvp arena's. This is one of the best nexon games out there. The download is fast and the controls are easy to use. Theres tons of people to meet. The game is full of 8 people dragon raid dungeons where you can earn uniqe items and equipment. Thier is so much to do in this world even if the animation style is a kiddish approach.

reviewText:
This game is... okay.

I love the art style, honestly the only actual problems are the server-side problems, how the client will crash or something similar.

Apparently this bug/error hasn't been fixed so that'll hurt this game's score from me super hardcore big time.

I love the character designs and pretty much alot about this game.

The glitches and bugs are offputting though, i can't deviate from them.

My client crashes every once in awhile, I'm sometimes ejected from the server. my client goes directly to desktop when it crashes. The anti-hack crap doesn't always load and therefore the game then also doesn't load. The game sometimes takes forever to launch, one time taking me over a half hour.

Until these bugs are fixed, this game can only earn a 2/10 in overall. Honestly a 9/10 in appearance and a 7/10 in gameplay. The 2/10 has the extra 1 point due to the fact the Kali class dances like a dirty stripper, which i eternally love to the ends of the earth.

Without that one thing... this game would be stuck at 1/10 for me.
